Reports: Joe Biden to announce candidacy for president Thursday

Autor: Newman, Meredith. 

Información de publicación: The News Journal ; Wilmington, Del. [Wilmington, Del]. 24 Apr 2019: A.2.

https://www.proquest.com/newspapers/reports-joe-biden-announce-candidacy-president/docview/2213045054/se-2?accountid=14708

Resumen: Ninguno disponible.

Enlaces: https://upfinder.upf.edu/openurl/34CSUC_UPF/34CSUC_UPF:VU1?genre=article&amp;atitle=Reports%3A+Joe+Biden+to+announce+candidacy+for+president+Thursday&amp;author=Newman%2C+Meredith&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;spage=A.2&amp;date=2019-04-24&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.jtitle=The+News+Journal&amp;issn=&amp;isbn=&amp;sid=ProQ%3Anortheastnews1_

Texto completo: Former Vice Joe Biden is expected to announce his candidacy for president on Thursday, bringing months of speculation to an end.
Both the New York Times and the Associated Press reported Tuesday that Biden will announce his candidacy in a video to be released Thursday.
Biden, 76, is then scheduled to speak in Pittsburgh on Monday.
For months, Biden has dropped hints about running for president, including when he told Delaware Democrats in March that he has the "most progressive record of anybody running."
This will be Biden's third attempt at a presidential run.
Although he's favored in some polls and is seen as the front-runner for the Democratic primary, Biden has faced criticism in recent weeks over his behavior and stances on certain issues.
In late March, Lucy Flores, a former Democratic Nevada assemblywoman wrote in an article published in the Cut that Biden made her uncomfortable when he put his hands on her shoulders, smelled her hair and gave her a "big slow kiss" on the back of her head at a political rally in 2014.
Flores' claim prompted inspection of Biden's past, including media analyses of previously published photos showing Biden interacting with women. Three more women have since spoken publicly about how Biden's behavior made them feel uncomfortable.
Others quickly came to his defense.
It prompted Biden to release a video on social media in which he said that he will be more "mindful and respectful of people's personal space" following allegations from women that his behavior has made them uncomfortable.
In recent weeks, the Biden campaign has made calls to prominent Democratic donors, the New York Times reported.
The country's largest firefighters union is planning to endorse the former vice president, according to AP.

____________________________________________________________

Charges against border group member from '17

Autor: KOCHERGA, ANGELA. 

Información de publicación: Albuquerque Journal ; Albuquerque [Albuquerque]. 23 Apr 2019.

https://www.proquest.com/newspapers/charges-against-border-group-member-17/docview/2212830531/se-2?accountid=14708

Resumen: LAS CRUCES The man who had identified himself as the “commander” of an armed group camped near the New Mexico border fence made an initial appearance in federal court on charges of being a felon in possession of firearms and ammunition. According to the criminal complaint, “Witnesses (in 2017) reported seeing members of the United Constitutional Patriots bearing firearms at Hopkins' residence.” The American Civil Liberties Union of New Mexico raised concerns the group was doing more than watching.

Enlaces: https://upfinder.upf.edu/openurl/34CSUC_UPF/34CSUC_UPF:VU1?genre=article&amp;atitle=Charges+against+border+group+member+from+%2717%3A+Complaint%3A+Organization+trained+to+assassinate+Obama%2C+others&amp;author=KOCHERGA%2C+ANGELA&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;spage=&amp;date=2019-04-23&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.jtitle=Albuquerque+Journal&amp;issn=1526-5137&amp;isbn=&amp;sid=ProQ%3Asouthcentralnews_

Texto completo: LAS CRUCES The man who had identified himself as the “commander” of an armed group camped near the New Mexico border fence made an initial appearance in federal court on charges of being a felon in possession of firearms and ammunition.
Larry Mitchell Hopkins, 69, wore a brown Doña Ana Detention Center jumpsuit and answered “yes” when U.S. Magistrate Gregory B. Wormuth asked if he understood the charges and his right to legal representation. When the judge asked about any medical problems, Hopkins said, “Quite a few medical problems, sir. I'm 70 years old.”
Hopkins, also known as Johnny Horton Jr., is from Flora Vista, according to the criminal complaint.
The charges stem from November 2017, when witnesses reported seeing weapons at his residence in Flora Vista and that the group he was involved in was training to kill Barack Obama and Hillary Clinton.
Hopkins has spent about two months living on the New Mexico border at a camp set up by the United Patriots of the Constitution. Sunland Park police and FBI agents arrested him Saturday.
“This arrest has absolutely nothing to do with what they're doing down there, on the surface anyway,” said Kelly O'Connell, Hopkins' lawyer.
A spokesman for the United Patriots insisted Hopkins was not armed while at the camp and served as the camp's cook.
The criminal complaint from 2017 accuses Hopkins of unlawful possession of nine firearms and ammunition in his home in San Juan County in November 2017. Hopkins has three felony convictions, including possessing a loaded firearm in Michigan in 1996, being a felon in possession of a firearm in Oregon and “impersonating a peace officer” in Oregon in 2006, according to the FBI.
According to the criminal complaint, “Witnesses (in 2017) reported seeing members of the United Constitutional Patriots bearing firearms at Hopkins' residence.” And the group was “training to assassinate George Soros, Hillary Clinton, and Barrak (Barack) Obama, because of these individuals' support of Antifa.” Antifa is described as a “loose collection of groups, networks and individuals who believe in active, aggressive opposition to far right-wing movements” on the Anti-Defamation League's website, which lists Antifa as an extremist group.
Outside the federal courthouse in Las Cruces, Hopkins' attorney said the guns and ammunition did not belong to his client. O'Connell said he was hired to represent Hopkins late Sunday night, but he declined to identify who is paying the legal costs.
There was no further reference to the threats in the complaint, which was filed Saturday.
The Journal interviewed Hopkins for its “8 hours on the border” series last month. At that time he identified himself as Johnny Horton and said he was a leader of the group.
“We're always armed. We don't point our weapons at people. But we're armed, because we don't know who is coming across,” he told the Journal.
“We talked to Border Patrol, and they said they needed help. They needed eyes,” he said. Border Patrol welcomes tips from citizens who witness illegal activity on the border but cautions people against taking the law into their own hands.
The American Civil Liberties Union of New Mexico raised concerns the group was doing more than watching. In a letter to the governor and attorney general Thursday, the ACLU referred to the men as “armed vigilantes” on the border who were “illegally detaining” hundreds of migrant families at gunpoint and called for an investigation.
The ACLU pointed to videos on social media that showed members of the group in camouflage standing over groups of migrant parents and kids.
“We are detaining people but not illegally. If they do not surrender to our verbal commands, we do not force them to stay with us,” Jim Benvie, the United Constitutional Patriots' spokesman, told the Journal on Thursday after learning about the ACLU letter.
The actions of the group have garnered national coverage both broadcast and print. The New York Times included a story on Monday's court appearance.
On Monday, Benvie reiterated the organization is not breaking any laws by patrolling the border with weapons.
“Our guys are carrying for protection. We're just a group of volunteer patriots, veterans in law enforcement,” Benvie said.
But he said Hopkins was not armed while living at the camp near the border fence. “He didn't have a gun. He didn't bring a gun. Johnny did not bring a gun,” he said.
“He's a 70-year-old Vietnam veteran who was cooking meals for people at the camp. He was a victim in this,” Benvie said.
Hopkins is being held without bond until his pretrial hearing in Albuquerque next Monday. Possible aid for asylum seekers
City Councilor Pat Davis proposes spending up to $250,000 to help immigrants METRO & NM, A5

Are Russian mobsters coming to Kentucky?

Información de publicación: Courier - Journal ; Louisville, Ky. [Louisville, Ky]. 23 Apr 2019: A.4.

https://www.proquest.com/newspapers/are-russian-mobsters-coming-kentucky/docview/2212620931/se-2?accountid=14708

Resumen: Ninguno disponible.

Enlaces: https://upfinder.upf.edu/openurl/34CSUC_UPF/34CSUC_UPF:VU1?genre=article&amp;atitle=Are+Russian+mobsters+coming+to+Kentucky%3F&amp;author=&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;spage=A.4&amp;date=2019-04-23&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.jtitle=Courier+-+Journal&amp;issn=1930-2177&amp;isbn=&amp;sid=ProQ%3Amidwestnews1_

Texto completo: Kentucky might be going into business with the Russian mafia.
Not the rough-and-tumble "Godfather" crowd with the bent noses and such names like Tessio, Barzini and Luca Brasi.
If all goes according to plan, by the middle of the year, we'll be in business with Oleg Deripaska, a buddy of Vladimir Putin.
He could be sending $200 million – if you believe media reports – in what could very well be mobbed-up money to northeastern Kentucky to build a $1.7 billion aluminum plant on an old strip mine there.
The United States government, according to the New York Times, has long believed that Deripaska has deep ties to Russian organized crime – the Bratva – so much so it has limited his travel here and prohibited him from doing business in this country.
The 51-year-old billionaire emerged as a powerful businessman following the 1991 fall of the Soviet Union after a bloody fight for control of Russia's aluminum industry.
Last November, the New York Times quoted Mikhail Khodorkovsky, another Russian billionaire, saying he stayed out of that battle and urged those he worked with to do the same because of the ruthlessness of the fight. "There were so many murders, I refused to go into this business," Khodorkovsky said.
According to the Times, many have claimed that Deripaska "engaged in theft, intimidation, bribery and even murder, notably of a Russian banker in 1995," but that none of those claims has been substantiated.
He was sued in Delaware in 2004 in a case that portrayed him as a "member of a criminal gang that seized control of an iron-ore mining complex in the Ural Mountains in the late 1990s," the Times wrote.
"The previous manager claimed that at a meeting attended by Mr. Deripaska, a mafia leader and five armed thugs, he was told to transfer a majority share or 'this is the last time you will leave here alive.'"
Deripaska denied the claims. The Delaware case was dismissed in 2007 because the American court didn't have jurisdiction.
Now Deripaska could be bringing his aluminum acumen to Kentucky.
That plant in which he and his company is investing is the Braidy Industries aluminum plant that Gov. Matt Bevin poured $15 million of your money into in 2017.
When he announced the planned aluminum mill, Bevin hailed it as possibly the "most singularly transformative economic development decision that has ever been made in the commonwealth of Kentucky."
But the plant has had trouble getting off the ground, in part because Braidy was forced to move the planned construction site from South Shore to Ashland when it was learned the original location couldn't support the weight of the plant.
And money was a problem.
Enter Rusal, a Russian aluminum company that until just three months ago was barred from doing business in the United States in part because of its ties to Deripaska.
The Trump administration lifted the sanctions in January after Deripaska agreed to reduce his ownership stake in the Moscow-based company, the world's second-largest aluminum manufacturer, from 70% to less than 45%.
And that came only after Senate Majority Leader Mitch McConnell backed that decision despite large numbers of Republicans and Democrats who objected to allowing Rusal and its parent company En+ Group into the United States.
The House voted to keep the sanctions 362-53, but the Senate fell three votes short of the 60 votes needed to end a filibuster. McConnell, along with fellow Kentucky Sen. Rand Paul, voted against the resolution.
Get ready for borscht and vodka in Ashland.
The deal is that Rusal will own 40% of the mill and will supply it with its reserves of aluminum from a smelter under construction in Siberia. Braidy will roll it flat so it can be used to make car parts here in the United States.
So, why would you go into business with a guy like Deripaska?
Craig T. Bouchard, the CEO of Braidy Industries, has lagged behind in raising money to build the plant, and has repeatedly extended the fundraising deadline. And Bouchard and his new best buddy, Bevin, need to get this operation moving, and they could only do that after getting hundreds of millions in loans. And they couldn't do that until they had private investors putting up approximately $500 million.
The plant is supposed to be fully operational in 2021. There's not a lot of time left.
But maybe, more importantly, Bevin faces reelection in November, and there has been an air of suspicion surrounding the Braidy project as it has dragged on. The question being asked: Is this project really going to happen?
Even Bevin's fellow Republicans have expressed doubt. Earlier this week, U.S. Rep. James Comer, a Republican from Kentucky's first district, said he wouldn't invest in Braidy and said he wouldn't have accepted the Russian investment. He didn't even address the issue of Deripaska's alleged involvement with Russian organized crime.
With the election fast approaching, perhaps Bevin is worried if this deal dies, his political career could be sleeping with the fishes.
Joseph Gerth's opinion column runs on most Sundays and at various times throughout the week. He can be reached at 502-582-4702 or by email at jgerth@courierjournal.com.
Joseph Gerth
Columnist
Louisville Courier Journal
USA TODAY NETWORK
Craig Bouchard is CEO of Braidy Industries, which is building an aluminum mill near Ashland, Ky.
John Flavell/Special to Courier Journal

How will we deal with the Julian Assange problem?

Información de publicación: The Daily Advertiser ; Lafayette, La. [Lafayette, La]. 22 Apr 2019: A.6.

https://www.proquest.com/newspapers/how-will-we-deal-with-julian-assange-problem/docview/2211895049/se-2?accountid=14708

Resumen: Ninguno disponible.

Enlaces: https://upfinder.upf.edu/openurl/34CSUC_UPF/34CSUC_UPF:VU1?genre=article&amp;atitle=How+will+we+deal+with+the+Julian+Assange+problem%3F&amp;author=&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;spage=A.6&amp;date=2019-04-22&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.jtitle=The+Daily+Advertiser&amp;issn=&amp;isbn=&amp;sid=ProQ%3Asouthcentralnews_

Texto completo: They say that guests are like fish; after three days they become a bit whiffy. By this measure, WikiLeaks founder Julian Assange smelled like an overladen fishing vessel adrift in the searing sun.
Upon his arrest Thursday by British authorities, ending his nearly seven-year asylum in the Ecuadorian Embassy in London, revelations emerged that he was less than an ideal guest. He reportedly was rude and aggressive toward his hosts and demonstrated little interest in hygiene. In his grossest display of disaffection, he apishly smeared his feces on the embassy walls, according to Ecuador's interior minister.
Assange's behavior makes one wonder about his mental health. Maybe he lost his mind while being confined for so long. On the other hand, he seemed quite cognizant as he left the embassy, offering peace signs and a thumbs-up to bystanders.
If Assange is, indeed, of right mind, then we can only conclude that he's a solid jerk. Certainly, his non-fans – including many in the U.S. media – long have viewed him as a sociopathic interloper operating under the protection of free speech. More on that anon.
No stranger to legal problems, Assange has been indicted by the U.S. on one count of conspiracy to commit computer intrusion. This sounds more like a stay-after-school offense than what one might expect given the potentially disastrous ramifications of Assange's publishing activities.
While the government seems to want to avoid a battle over the First Amendment, focusing mostly on conspiracy, it can later charge Assange with something more. Meanwhile, media talk has turned to whether Assange is really a journalist and if free-speech protections ought to apply to someone who is (allegedly) a criminal first? Despite the recent surge in "citizen journalists," saying you're a journalist doesn't make you one. (Granted, some are better than the "real" ones.)
The difference between someone like Assange publishing whatever leaks land in his lap and, say, The Washington Post, which published the leaked documents known as the Pentagon Papers, is mostly a lot of worry and process. Most responsible reporters and editors routinely ask themselves questions such as: Should we publish this? Does the public interest override other concerns? Is it justifiable to expose someone's personal emails and under what circumstances?
One supposes that Assange never bothered himself with such pesky queries. But then, why should he? He is not, after all, a journalist, despite his claiming to be, because he isn't accountable to anyone. No filters, no standards.
In the case of the Pentagon Papers, former Rand Corp. military analyst Daniel Ellsberg stole thousands of pages of a top-secret report detailing the U.S. government's decades-long campaign of deceit, mayhem and murder related to the war in Vietnam. Ellsberg first gave the documents to The New York Times, which published three articles about them before the White House obtained a court injunction. Ellsberg then provided copies to the Post, which, after due consideration, began publishing its own stories.
In deliberating whether to run them, Post publisher Katharine Graham deployed lawyers and editors to weigh the potential legal and commercial consequences against allowing the government to continue lying and sacrificing lives. Graham's bravery in standing up to the U.S. government and the courts – all while risking great personal and financial loss – was epic.
Assange's process, on the other hand, is largely to dump secrets in the town square and let the scavengers sort it out. No filter. No conscience.
It isn't hyperbolic to say we're at a hinge point regarding how we gather and disseminate information. Does anyone have the right to publish stolen/classified materials? Should the manner of obtaining information inform the right to publish? For now, at least, the Assange case provides little help, but precedent may offer clues.
On the surface, Ellsberg and Assange seem similar. Ellsberg stole – and newspapers published. Assange allegedly conspired to steal – and he published. The difference may be mostly political.
The Vietnam War was unpopular, and the government demonstrably lied to the American people for decades, unconscionably committing tens of thousands of young Americans to their early graves. Ellsberg's charges on theft, conspiracy and espionage were eventually dismissed.
Wikileaks leaked hundreds of thousands of secret documents that potentially endangered Americans and allies around the world and, possibly, helped get Donald Trump elected.
One was a historic act of bravery; the other seems more like feces-smearing by a fishy-smelling "cypherpunk." Then again, maybe that's just me.
Kathleen Parker's email address is kathleenparker@washpost.com.
Kathleen Parker
Columnist
WikiLeaks founder Julian Assange has been indicted by the U.S. on one count of conspiracy to commit computer intrusion.
Jack Taylor/Getty Images
Kathleen Parker
Columnist

Couple who tortured 12 children sentenced to life

Autor: Hartocollis, Anemona. 

Información de publicación: Philadelphia Tribune ; Philadelphia, Pa. [Philadelphia, Pa]. 21 Apr 2019: 8A.

https://www.proquest.com/newspapers/couple-who-tortured-12-children-sentenced-life/docview/2222552368/se-2?accountid=14708

Resumen: Ninguno disponible.

Enlaces: https://upfinder.upf.edu/openurl/34CSUC_UPF/34CSUC_UPF:VU1?genre=article&amp;atitle=Couple+who+tortured+12+children+sentenced+to+life&amp;author=Hartocollis%2C+Anemona&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;spage=8A&amp;date=2019-04-21&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.jtitle=Philadelphia+Tribune&amp;issn=0746-956X&amp;isbn=&amp;sid=ProQ%3Anortheastnews1_

Texto completo: LOS ANGELES - A California couple who tortured 12 of their 13 children, starving and beating them, depriving them of sleep and sometimes shackling them to their beds with chains, were sentenced Friday to 25 years to life in prison.
Some of their children gave statements at the sentencing hearing, saying they were haunted by the abuse they suffered, but also saying in some cases that they had forgiven and still loved their parents. One of their daughters told a packed courtroom that the suffering "may have been bad, but it made me strong."
"My parents took my whole life from me, but now I'm taking my life back," said the young woman, who is now in college. She added, "I'm a fighter. I'm strong."
The couple, David and Louise Turpin, cried and trembled as four of their children made statements, two of them through inter-mediaries, in Riverside County Superior Court.
One of the children, a young man who is studying software engineering at college, said that he had learned to ride a bike since being rescued. "Sometimes I just go on long rides because I enjoy it so much," he said.
The children were rescued in January 2018 after one of the girls worked up the courage to escape by jumping from a window of the suburban Los Angeles home where they had been kept prisoner. She called 911 from a cellphone she had grabbed from the house, and in a calm, clear voice described the years of abuse to a police dispatcher.
"I've never been out. I don't go out much," the girl told the dispatcher. She was 17, but her voice sounded like that of a much younger child, because, prosecutors said, her growth had been stunted by the abuse. The abuse left two of her sisters unable to bear children, authorities said.
Now, in a reversal of fate, the parents, who pleaded guilty to multiple counts of torture and abuse, are likely to spend the rest of their lives locked up. They will be eligible for parole after 25 years, prosecutors said, but unless a parole board decides otherwise, they will probably remain in prison for life.
The children ranged from 2 to 29 years old when they were found. Some were emaciated and appeared to have cognitive deficiencies from the abuse. Only the . toddler did not appear to have been abused, authorities said.
To their neighbors, the family seemed normal, if reclusive. David Turpin, 57, had been an engineer for Lockheed Martin and Northrop Grumman. Louise Turpin, 50, apparently stayed home. They lived in a nondescript stucco home in the small working class city of Perris, about 70 miles east of Los Angeles.
Neighbors rarely saw the children outside the home. It was neatly kept on the outside, and so did not arouse suspicion. But it reeked of human waste on the inside, where the children were often not released from their shackles to go to the bathroom.
- (The New York Times)

Adult comedy soars in Station's 'Bird'

Autor: Jenkins, Jeffrey Eric. 

Información de publicación: News Gazette ; Champaign, Ill. [Champaign, Ill]. 21 Apr 2019: E.7.

https://www.proquest.com/newspapers/adult-comedy-soars-stations-bird/docview/2213390477/se-2?accountid=14708

Resumen: In Jadon Peck's impressionistic scene design, which suggests a range of rustic locations near a lake glimpsed through painted panels at the rear of the tiny Station Theatre, a prominent photograph of Chekhov looms as an icon calling forth the work's Russian soul. Adapting the piece for seven principal characters instead of the usual dozen or so, playwright Posner nimbly deploys Chekhovian themes on the significance of love and art in human experience to create a trio of couples who are by turns star-matched and star-crossed. Conrad (Jake Fava) overflows with artistic and romantic desire in his quest for "new forms" of theatrical expression as he seeks to impress his vain, dismissive mother, Emma (Joi Hoffsommer), and his prospective paramour, Nina (Lindsey Gates-Markel).

Enlaces: https://upfinder.upf.edu/openurl/34CSUC_UPF/34CSUC_UPF:VU1?genre=article&amp;atitle=Adult+comedy+soars+in+Station%27s+%27Bird%27&amp;author=Jenkins%2C+Jeffrey+Eric&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;spage=E.7&amp;date=2019-04-21&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.jtitle=News+Gazette&amp;issn=1042-3354&amp;isbn=&amp;sid=ProQ%3Amidwestnews1_

Texto completo: In the dusty archives of a famed actors' club in St. Petersburg, Russia, a bust of the great dramatist Anton Chekhov peers down at mere mortals who sit at a table near the bookcase where he is perched. Why would this come to mind at Thursday night's opening of "Stupid _______ Bird" by Aaron Posner at the Station Theatre in Urbana?
In Jadon Peck's impressionistic scene design, which suggests a range of rustic locations near a lake glimpsed through painted panels at the rear of the tiny Station Theatre, a prominent photograph of Chekhov looms as an icon calling forth the work's Russian soul.
This play with The News-Gazette's mandated blank space is "sort of" based on the Russian master's classic "The Seagull." The missing word is a vulgar adjective frequently employed throughout the play.
The characters are not, however, 19th-century denizens of a Russian dacha. These refugees (spinoffs?) from Chekhov speak the argot of today's version of bohemian culture. Adapting the piece for seven principal characters instead of the usual dozen or so, playwright Posner nimbly deploys Chekhovian themes on the significance of love and art in human experience to create a trio of couples who are by turns star-matched and star-crossed.
Conrad (Jake Fava) overflows with artistic and romantic desire in his quest for "new forms" of theatrical expression as he seeks to impress his vain, dismissive mother, Emma (Joi Hoffsommer), and his prospective paramour, Nina (Lindsey Gates-Markel). It is a lot of pressure for an intense young man whose sap is rising and who feels overshadowed by his actor mother and her lover, Trigorin (Gary Ambler), a famed literary figure.
As counterpoint to these couples, Posner offers two young people from the less-privileged classes, Dev (Eric Beckley) and Mash (Hannah Yonan). Mash pines for the young writer, Con, who barely acknowledges her existence. She wears black because, she says, "I'm in mourning. For my life. I'm unhappy."
For his part, Dev, whom another character describes as Con's "odd friend," carries the torch of unrequited love for Mash and good-naturedly argues with her over which of them is more miserable. When Mash wonders if they are characters in "a Dickens novel," we are reminded that this is not Chekhov, it's Posner, but as in Chekhov (and life), everyone's a little miserable.
Acting as a choric presence for the play is Sorn (William L. Kephart), an aging doctor who is Emma's brother and Con's supportive uncle. It is he who attempts to soothe troubled waters between his sister and nephew, who ruminates on the meaning of it all, and who unsettles the audience with his conclusions about human nature and purpose.
A key difference between Posner's "Bird" and Chekhov's "Seagull" comes in the current play's use of direct address to the audience. Chekhov is noted for his use of indirection, with key events often happening offstage so that audiences witness how characters react to the fact of these actions.
In Posner's comic view, however, indirection is overcome as characters break the "fourth wall," unburdening themselves of their cares and woes. They beg us to recognize them, to feel their pain, and ask us (literally) for advice. Something may be lost in this shifted paradigm, but much accessible adult humor is gained and Con's plaintive cry for new forms comes flickering to life.
Director Kay Bohannon Holley has cobbled a tight ensemble of actors, several of whom have worked together in the past. Fava's heated passion as the young artist sometimes feels as though it might overwhelm the intimacy of the theater space, but he wisely holds himself in reserve. Yonan's Mash is a revelation that makes us wonder why Con is blind to her many charms.
Beckley, as Dev, provides a needed and delightful balance to Mash and Con's intensity. As Nina, the heartbreaker who finds the making of art a crushing challenge, Gates-Markel floats through the play as if she were a butterfly who stings. She never lands for long, but she leaves pain in her wake. Like every true artist, she says, "I go on."
Stage veterans Hoffsommer and Ambler are well matched as a power couple among the literati in their world. Hoffsommer's Emma delivers a poignant speech on the satisfactions of winter romance that drives Trigorin back into her arms, for a while anyway. Kephart's Sorn provides many pleasures with warm, open connection to the other characters and to the audience.
There is much to admire in "Bird," but when the characters ask for advice, we want to say, "Stop wanting what is not yours."
Easier said than done. Don't you think?
Parental warning: The production has nudity and adult language and themes.
Jeffrey Eric Jenkins is a professor at the University of Illinois. His theater writing has appeared in many publications, including the Seattle Post-Intelligencer and The New York Times.
If you go

Where: Station Theatre, 223 Broadway Ave., U.
When: Through May 4. Shows are Wednesdays through Sundays at 7:30 p.m., except April 28, when the show is at 3 p.m.
Tickets: Regular admission is $15. $10 for students and seniors.
Box office: Online via stationtheatre.com or by phone at 1-800-838-3006.

Modell's taps financial adviser to help its business

Autor: Anzidei, Melanie. 

Información de publicación: Courier - News ; Bridgewater, N.J. [Bridgewater, N.J]. 21 Apr 2019: A.1.

https://www.proquest.com/newspapers/modells-taps-financial-adviser-help-business/docview/2211740157/se-2?accountid=14708

Resumen: Ninguno disponible.

Enlaces: https://upfinder.upf.edu/openurl/34CSUC_UPF/34CSUC_UPF:VU1?genre=article&amp;atitle=Modell%27s+taps+financial+adviser+to+help+its+business&amp;author=Anzidei%2C+Melanie&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;spage=A.1&amp;date=2019-04-21&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.jtitle=Courier+-+News&amp;issn=0895-8785&amp;isbn=&amp;sid=ProQ%3Anortheastnews1_

Texto completo: Modell's Sporting Goods, known for its catchy "Gotta Go To Mo's" jingle, has obtained guidance from a financial adviser — an indication that the country's oldest sporting goods store is facing mounting pressure in today's competitive retail climate.
The Manhattan-based retailer, which has more than 150 stores in the Northeast, including dozens in New York and New Jersey, has tapped California-based consulting firm Berkeley Research Group, the same adviser that worked with Modell's in 2017 and that has advised other troubled retailers like Gymboree Group Inc.
Retail experts say it is not unusual for retailers to reposition themselves in the ever-changing world of retail, where competition from big-box stores and online shopping has forced a growing list of retailers to file for bankruptcy in the first four months of 2019 alone, including Charlotte Russe and Payless ShoeSource.
Mitchell Modell, the retailer's chief executive, said the retailer has long-term plans to stay in business.,
"We are committed to securing our future in a challenging retail climate, and therefore are always looking for ways to improve our performance," Modell said in an emailed statement responding to questions from the USA TODAY NETWORK New Jersey. "To help us with efficiencies and process improvement, we have engaged Berkeley Research Group, as we have done in the past."
Modell, a resident of Alpine, did not specify what the company's plans were. When asked if stores would be closing in New Jersey or New York, he said the retailer had no plans to shutter stores in those markets, beyond closures that he said occur annually when leases expire.
The Wall Street Journal first reported in March that Modell's hired Berkeley Research Group. In the report, people familiar with the matter said options on the table included a possible bankruptcy filing or restructuring.
Should the retailer eventually file for bankruptcy or plan any widespread closures, it could send shock waves across New York and New Jersey's retail sectors. The chain has an estimated 100 stores in the two states, according to a count on the company's website. That's about one-third of the chain's retail footprint.
Widespread closures could have a big impact on the region's commercial real estate market, which has recently had to absorb the closure of Toys R Us and Sears stores, and must deal with planned closures of some Bed Bath & Beyond stores soon.
Retailers typically hire financial advisers when the future of their companies is uncertain, and because advisers can offer an objective approach to dealing with a distressed company, said Ted Gavin, managing director of Gavin/Solmonese, a bankruptcy and restructuring consulting firm.
Modell's likely hired an adviser "because they have a fundamental business problem that is threatening the future of the company, and that is in all likelihood a combination of too little revenue and burdensome leases," Gavin said.
Gavin, who has more than 20 years of experience working with distressed companies, said Modell's may consider getting out of under-performing markets.
That, he said, is key to balancing other financial strains a retailer may be facing, whether too much debt or declining sales in particular stores.
"The key is to get out of the markets that aren't working for you and to do it early enough to be able to preserve cash," Gavin said. "Moving to online may supplement what you lose in closing retail — but the important thing is to get out of money-losing retail locations."
An immigrant from Hungary The retail world has been unforgiving to sporting goods companies, but Modell's, the oldest family-owned sporting goods company in the country, has managed to stay afloat amid the changing tides.
The business started when Morris A. Modell, an immigrant from Hungary, opened a general store on Cortlandt Street in Lower Manhattan in 1889 — a date that has been affixed on the store's red-and-white signs for decades. The company thrived after World War I by stocking up on Army surplus merchandise and selling it at low prices, according to William Modell's obituary in The New York Times.
William Modell, the third generation to run the business, profited from the failures of his rivals, the Times reported. In 1996, Modell's grew from 67 stores by paying $2.5 million for 15 outlets in New Jersey and in the Baltimore and Washington areas from bankrupt Herman's World of Sporting Goods.
Modell's reportedly considered a similar strategy in 2016 when Sports Authority liquidated all its stores. Modell's planned to bid on some of Sports Authority's failed stores, but that plan was never executed.
Often, the competition between sporting goods companies has been fierce. Dick's Sporting Goods, arguably, fast-tracked Sports Authority's demise — the big-box chain had a strategy of placing its new stores as close as possible to existing Sports Authority locations, taking away sales from the struggling retailer.
Today, Dick's Sporting Goods remains a dominant player. Founded in 1948, the company has ballooned and now operates 729 stores.
But even the successful chain experienced softening sales, and has plans to up its in-store and online game in 2019, officials said in the company's latest earnings release.
Modell's, by comparison, has a much smaller footprint that is exclusive to the Northeast.
Urban strategy The chain has more than 30 stores in New Jersey, and nearly 70 locations across New York, with most concentrated in New York City. Modell's also has dozens of stores scattered throughout Pennsylvania, Connecticut, Massachusetts, New Hampshire, Delaware, Virginia and the District of Columbia.
The chain has concentrated its retail footprint largely in urban areas, in or near cities like Philadelphia, Baltimore, Washington D.C., and Boston.
The retailer's strategy to concentrate on a specific market, experts say, is what may have kept it afloat while other sporting goods chains fell by the wayside.
"They've always been a wise retailer," said Chuck Lanyard, president of retail brokerage firm The Goldstein Group in Paramus. "Over 20 years ago, they began to focus on a lot of inner-city sporting supplies, because they really met the niche for that urban, inner-city sporting good store."
For instance, the chain has a prominent location inside Center City Mall in Paterson. Alma Realty, which owns the property, declined to comment about the store's lease.
Shutting some stores, especially in weak markets where sales may be lagging, is typical for a retailer, Lanyard said. Often, a retailer may shut stores in under-performing markets to concentrate on profitable locations or on other ways to make money, he said.
"Very often we see tenants do the right thing in trying to really reposition themselves," Lanyard said. "Retailers recognize that there's other ways of making money — including doing internet business, in exchange for less bricks and mortar."
Local footprints Earlier this year, a Modell's in the Arlington Shopping Plaza on Route 46 in Parsippany closed after the holiday season.
That Modell's is one of two big-box vacancies inside the shopping plaza. The shell of a former K-Mart sits at the opposite end of the plaza. The Bed, Bath & Beyond store that is in the center, anchored with a Home Depot, is expected to close by summer — when that store's lease expires.
Just this week, Union-based Bed, Bath & Beyond announced plans to shutter an estimated 40 stores to make way for 15 new locations.
Modell's also has a store in Paramus, which is considered by many the retail mecca of Bergen County.
Lanyard, who heads his firm's Paramus team, said the borough is usually a retailer's strongest market. That's why, should a retailer close or give up on a market as lucrative as Paramus, it can be an indicator that a company is headed on a downward spiral.
"The reality is when stores close in Paramus, it usually means [retailers are] giving up on some of their strongest markets, which means they probably won't last," Lanyard said.
The Modell's on Route 4 in the Paramus Place Shopping Center is small, and sits near a much-larger Kohl's department store. Officials from the center did not respond to questions about the Modell's location. However, the store displayed a "now hiring" sign on its front window this week.
It remains to be seen what Modell's future will be. However, Gavin, the managing director of the bankruptcy and restructuring consulting firm, said that when retailers seem to be heading toward bankruptcy, "they usually get there."
A shuttered Modell's Sporting Goods store in Parsippany is shown on March 7.
Melanie Anzidei/ USA TODAY NETWORK - NEW JERSEY

The Lakers' Magic Is Gone, in More Ways Than One

Autor: Stein, Marc. 

Información de publicación: New York Times , Late Edition (East Coast); New York, N.Y. [New York, N.Y]. 21 Apr 2019: SP.3.

https://www.proquest.com/newspapers/lakers-magic-is-gone-more-ways-than-one/docview/2211711303/se-2?accountid=14708

Resumen: Ninguno disponible.

Enlaces: https://upfinder.upf.edu/openurl/34CSUC_UPF/34CSUC_UPF:VU1?genre=article&amp;atitle=The+Lakers%27+Magic+Is+Gone%2C+in+More+Ways+Than+One%3A+%5BSports+Desk%5D&amp;author=Stein%2C+Marc&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;spage=SP.3&amp;date=2019-04-21&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.jtitle=New+York+Times&amp;issn=0362-4331&amp;isbn=&amp;sid=ProQ%3Anytimes_

Texto completo: The city of Los Angeles has never belonged to the Clippers. You feel reasonably safe saying that it never will.
You can also credibly say that the gap between them and the storied Lakers has never looked smaller.
The Clippers on Monday night completed the greatest playoff comeback in N.B.A. history when they overturned a 31-point deficit in the second half to stun the two-time defending champion Golden State Warriors. Heading into a free-agent summer in which the Clippers are widely expected to beat their more glamorous Staples Center co-tenants to a superstar's signature, L.A.'s long-mocked "other" team has a roster full of never-quit scrappers whom you can already crown this season's undisputed Play Hard champions.
The Lakers, meanwhile, are mere days removed from the most disappointing season in franchise history -- with little evidence to suggest that the team's primary owner, Jeanie Buss, is prepared to take the necessary steps to steer them back to a winning course.
It has not quite reached the point that the inhabitants of Lakerland are clamoring for the return of the beleaguered Jim Buss. The Lakers, after all, did manage to sign LeBron James within 18 months of Jeanie Buss pushing out her brother Jim as the team's top basketball decision maker and replacing him with Magic Johnson.
But Johnson's abrupt April 9 resignation left Buss with a mess -- and a clear task. After six straight seasons of losing, as James nears his 35th birthday in December, there is a justified clamor to break from the outdated Lakers tradition of restricting their outreach to job candidates with well-established ties to the franchise.
Perhaps that looms somewhere in yet-to-be-announced plans, but the signals so far point to Buss refusing to modernize the franchise and instead allowing Johnson's top aide, Rob Pelinka, to assume greater responsibility and run the team's basketball operations.
Which would be the worst mistake of her tenure.
Pelinka is already running the Lakers' search for a new coach. The opening was created when the under-fire Luke Walton surrendered the final two years of his contract after months of withering scrutiny and pressure, largely instigated by Johnson's well-chronicled criticism in November, in part because he knew he could walk straight into a better opportunity and more tangible support from the woebegone Sacramento Kings.
In numerous rival organizations, there is both shock and relief that the Lakers haven't responded to events of the past week-plus by chasing the likes of Golden State's Bob Myers, San Antonio's R. C. Buford and Oklahoma City's Sam Presti before they go looking for a new coach.
That is the blueprint Golden State followed to build a championship organization. The highly rated Myers and Rick Welts were hired to oversee basketball and business matters -- with Jerry West was brought in as a consultant. All of that happened before Steve Kerr became Golden State's coach.
Steve Ballmer, the Clippers' deep-pocketed owner, invoked similar thinking in his bid to build a brain trust to try to compete with the league's most feared franchise. Ballmer hired West away from the Warriors and imported Michael Winger, the well-regarded salary-cap specialist, to flank Lawrence Frank in a revamped front office after Coach Doc Rivers was stripped of personnel power.
The 76ers tried to stage their own such coup last summer after the Bryan Colangelo Twitter scandal. As The New York Times reported last July, Philadelphia made an ambitious attempt at hiring Daryl Morey away from Houston -- and I'm told Philly also commissioned a clandestine run at prying Myers away from the Warriors that was likewise rebuffed.
Yet another example: Just last week, amid the latest outbreak of Lakers chaos, New Orleans quietly gave itself a major credibility boost by persuading David Griffin, arguably the most accomplished executive without a job, to take on the challenge of rebuilding the Pelicans in the wake of Anthony Davis's trade demand in January.
The Lakers, like Philadelphia, could certainly be foiled if they pursued a superstar general manager. But why not try? The easiest marquee free agents to sign are general managers and coaches -- those whose salaries need not fit under the cap.
Industry estimates suggest Morey's recent contract extension from the Rockets pays him in the $8 million range annually. Johnson was earning an estimated $10 million as the Lakers' team president. Given the TV riches that the Lakers bring in, Buss could presumably double those figures in a pitch to any of the game's elite executives.
Buss's defenders may try to point out that the Lakers did follow an element of the Golden State model by hiring Pelinka, given his prior run as a successful player agent the way Myers was. But Myers has always been a popular figure in league circles who also spent a full season observing Golden State's operation before he was elevated to general manager. Maintaining strong relationships within his own organization and throughout the league is one of Myers's strengths.
Pelinka, to be blunt, is not Myers. He is Kobe Bryant's former agent, but also a polarizing figure whose time with the Lakers has spawned numerous recent reports about trust issues -- not only in his dealings with other teams and former rivals in the agent world, but also former Lakers players (Larry Nance Jr. and Andrew Bogut) who were jettisoned after broken promises. The perception persists that he ascended to power with the Lakers solely via Bryant's push.
The Lakers would argue that Pelinka has received an unfair share of criticism for his work. Yet a succession of questionable choices in roster construction, while they belong to Johnson as much as Pelinka, has only lowered Pelinka's approval rating further. Ditto for Jeanie Buss's, since she appears to be Pelinka's most ardent supporter.
The Lakers responded to Johnson's sudden exit by vowing to "work in a measured and methodical fashion to make the right moves for the future." What that means so far is interviews for their coaching vacancy with Monty Williams, the in-demand assistant coach of the 76ers, and Tyronn Lue, the former Cleveland Cavaliers coach. The Miami Heat assistant Juwan Howard is another known candidate, but a buzz is already circulating in coaching circles that Williams has a stronger-than-expected shot at the job because some in the Lakers' organization may fear hiring Lue would be giving James too much control.
Buss couldn't have honored her father's keep-it-in-the-family philosophy any better than by giving Johnson first crack to lead the Lakers back to glory. History won't be kind to Johnson's tenure as team president or how it ended, on top of a failed 16-game stint as coach of the Lakers at the end of the 1993-94 season, but he will ultimately be forgiven for every stumble because he's Magic Johnson -- maybe the greatest winner this franchise has ever employed and certainly its most charismatic.
Buss, by contrast, won't receive anything close to the same luxury if she persists with the status quo and the Lakers continue to lag behind the norms of the 21st century N.B.A. Post-Magic, she will get one mulligan. Not two.
The Clippers will realistically never fully close the gap, but they're starting to get uncomfortably close. They just gave the Warriors an almighty scare in this first-round series with what they already have -- and they're routinely billed as the favorites to sign Kawhi Leonard in free agency in July.
The Lakers, as a result, need professional help as quickly as they can find it.
Going beyond the borders of yesteryear is the first place they should be looking.

A new category for Netflix, Brene Brown

Información de publicación: The Sun ; Lowell, Mass. [Lowell, Mass]. 20 Apr 2019.

https://www.proquest.com/newspapers/new-category-netflix-brene-brown/docview/2211573515/se-2?accountid=14708

Resumen: Ninguno disponible.

Enlaces: https://upfinder.upf.edu/openurl/34CSUC_UPF/34CSUC_UPF:VU1?genre=article&amp;atitle=A+new+category+for+Netflix%2C+Brene+Brown&amp;author=&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;spage=&amp;date=2019-04-20&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.jtitle=The+Sun&amp;issn=&amp;isbn=&amp;sid=ProQ%3Anortheastnews1_

Texto completo: NASHVILLE, Tenn. (AP) -- Brene Brown's books on shame, vulnerability and courage have given her A-list fans like Oprah and Melinda Gates and made her a go-to leadership consultant for both Pixar and the Seattle Seahawks.

But Brown, a research professor at the University of Houston's Graduate College of Social Work, thought she'd spend her career writing for other academics, not making The New York Times' best-seller list.

"My goal was to put it in peer-reviewed articles that no one would read but, like, five people and they would just read it to check to make sure they were quoted," Brown told The Associated Press from her home in Houston.

Five best-selling books later, Brown debuted her first Netflix special Friday, "Brene Brown: The Call to Courage," based on her two decades of research. The special is a bit of an experiment for the streaming service, the categories of which Brown doesn't neatly fit into.

"Am I comedy? Documentary? True crime?" Brown joked.

Brown's skill as a writer and speaker is that she doesn't sound like a typical self-help or leadership expert who is shouting motivational mantras. She has a researcher's mind for patterns and a storyteller's gift of language. She peppers her talks with plenty of Texas colloquialisms, like "There's nothing in the middle of the road but white stripes and dead armadillos." She tells personal anecdotes about her kids and her husband to illustrate her broader ideas about parenting, compassion, leadership and more.

"People will come up to me and say, 'I already knew everything you said. I just didn't have the language to say it. I didn't know we were allowed to talk about it,"' said Brown. "And so I think I just put language around feelings and experiences and thoughts that we all have."

She can also curse like a true Southern lady, which is just enough to set people at ease and give them a laugh. "Not like Andrew Dice Clay," she said. "An appropriate amount of cursing."

In the special, she talks about her 2010 speech on vulnerability that has become one of the most watched TED Talk speeches, now viewed about 39 million times. Her most recent book, "Dare to Lead: Brave Work. Tough Conversations. Whole Hearts," is a playbook for leading with empathy.

When asked about leadership qualities she hopes to see among candidates for the upcoming 2020 U.S. presidential election, Brown took a long pause.

"I am one inch away from being completely disenchanted with politics but I'm holding on. I'm white-knuckling it right now," she said. "I need a political system where the people who make the decisions actually are required to live by them and are not in such an elite position where they make policy and laws and financial decisions that don't affect them."

The Netflix special is good timing for Brown, who has spent years traveling all over the country giving speeches to corporations, entrepreneurs, women's conferences and leadership training events.

Her youngest child is in middle school, and she's moving into a period of her career where she's doing less of those speaking opportunities in order to be at home. But with Netflix, she has a chance to continue building on the conversations she started with her books.

"This opportunity from Netflix just felt like such a deeply important gift," Brown said. "This thing is going to drop in 190 countries."

Wolf Pack 'first lady'

Autor: McAndrew, Siobhan. 

Información de publicación: Reno Gazette - Journal ; Reno, Nev. [Reno, Nev]. 20 Apr 2019: A.4.

https://www.proquest.com/newspapers/wolf-pack-first-lady/docview/2211524756/se-2?accountid=14708

Resumen: Ninguno disponible.

Enlaces: https://upfinder.upf.edu/openurl/34CSUC_UPF/34CSUC_UPF:VU1?genre=article&amp;atitle=Wolf+Pack+%27first+lady%27%3A+Tanya+Alford+will+be+loudest+one+in+Lawlor&amp;author=McAndrew%2C+Siobhan&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;spage=A.4&amp;date=2019-04-20&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.jtitle=Reno+Gazette+-+Journal&amp;issn=&amp;isbn=&amp;sid=ProQ%3Awestnews_

Texto completo: "I'm just passionate about basketball. I just always have been."
Tayna Alford
It doesn't surprise Tanya Alford that her husband, Steve, signed the longest contract ever given to a coach at the University of Nevada, Reno.
But the Nevada men's basketball coach contract for 10 years and $11.5 million is nothing compared to her 32 year marriage.
While Steve Alford may have been given the coaching job, Nevada's newest first lady of the men's basketball program is ready to become a part of the Wolf Pack brand.
Her predecessor Danyelle Musselman, married to now Arkansas coach Eric Musselman, was a visible face in the community. The former TV sports anchor often took to the microphone leading charity events.
Tanya Alford said she also plans to get involved in charities but, unlike Danyelle Musselman who appeared calm from across the court, she is likely to be screaming during games.
"I'll be the loudest person in the gym," said Tayna Alford, who sat in the front row during a press conference at Lawlor Events Center on April 12.
A net, a ring and a proposal at Indiana Tanya Alford has been her husband's cheerleader since the two started dating in high school.
They met in the fifth grade. Both students in New Castle, Indiana, the two went on to college together at Indiana.
She would rebound for him as he made practice shots.
At the end of their junior year in college, the two walked into the gym and the net was caught on the rim.
After Steve Alford carried the ladder and put it under the basket, she climbed up as she had done countless times to untangle the net.
But this time, Alford put an engagement ring on the back of the rim.
Tanya has been a force behind her husband's success, including winning an Olympic Gold medal in 1984 to an NCAA championship in 1987.
After four NBA seasons for Dallas and Golden State, the couple went on to coaching posts in Missouri, Iowa, New Mexico and Los Angeles.
The couple has three children, now all in their 20s. They include daughter Kayla and sons Bryce and Kory, who played for UCLA under their father.
In 2015 Tanya Alford told the New York Times, "Dealing with the ups and downs of this game is what we're used to because basketball is part of our family's DNA."
The story talked about how she mimicked her husband's calls and hand gestures during a UCLA game and was on the sidelines decked out in a Bruins gear and fingernails painted in school colors.
"I'm just passionate about basketball," she told the Reno Gazette Journal. "I just always have been."
"I'm just passionate about basketball. I just always have been."
Tayna Alford
UCLA head coach Steve Alford and his son, guard Bryce Alford, look on during an NCAA college basketball game against Kansas in the second round of the Maui Invitational in 2015 in Lahaina, Hawaii.
The Associated Press
CREDIT: Siobhan McAndrew

____________________________________________________________

Answers to Readers' Questions

Información de publicación: New York Times , Late Edition (East Coast); New York, N.Y. [New York, N.Y]. 20 Apr 2019: A.12.

https://www.proquest.com/newspapers/answers-readers-questions/docview/2211505573/se-2?accountid=14708

Resumen: Ninguno disponible.

Enlaces: https://upfinder.upf.edu/openurl/34CSUC_UPF/34CSUC_UPF:VU1?genre=article&amp;atitle=Answers+to+Readers%27+Questions%3A+%5BNational+Desk%5D&amp;author=&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;spage=A.12&amp;date=2019-04-20&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.jtitle=New+York+Times&amp;issn=0362-4331&amp;isbn=&amp;sid=ProQ%3Anytimes_

Texto completo: Almost two years after the Mueller investigation began, the special counsel's findings, submitted last month, have become public. On Thursday, Attorney General William P. Barr released a redacted version of the more than 400-page report.
[ Read about the report delivered to Congress and the public. ]
We asked readers what they wanted to know about it and received nearly 900 questions. Our journalists in Washington who covered the investigation and what came after answered a selection.
______
The Report's Release
How much was redacted?
Rosalie Baine, Atlanta
As journalists, we would say too much was redacted. We naturally want the public to know everything. But the redactions generally hewed closely to what the Justice Department predicted. Grand jury material was excised, as was material related to a few ongoing matters.
We don't know what we aren't seeing, of course, but we didn't see an obvious effort to black out material that was damaging or embarrassing to the president.
-- Matt Apuzzo
Are redacted portions of a report like this ever open to the public? Is that going to be 100 years from now?
Stacie Scholz, Edmonds, Wash.
As far as we know, the redacted portions will never be open to the public. Congressional leaders should be able to see a less redacted version -- meaning everything except grand jury material -- but that is still not supposed to be made public.
-- Maggie Haberman
What about the summaries prepared by Mueller's team? Have they been released and are they redacted?
Mark Correll, Boulder, Colo.
Yes, executive summaries written by Mr. Mueller's team have been included in the report. The more than 400-page document is divided into two volumes, each of which begins with an introduction and executive summary of the contents. Several sentences in each summary have been redacted, in almost every case because of what Mr. Barr deemed would cause potential "harm to an ongoing matter." -- Nicholas Fandos
I'm curious to know what it took to make all the redactions in the report. Was it a team as big as the New York Times one reviewing the report?
Carl Williams, Newark, N.J.
We don't know the answer to that yet, and may not for a while.
-- Maggie Haberman
I'm having a hard time reconciling Barr's comments with the report's contents and obvious spinning in favor of Trump. Barr's behavior seems bizarre; how will this be reconciled? Congress makes the laws, not Barr. His comments seem in conflict with Mueller's report? Confused.
Monica Spencer, Vancouver, Wash.
In theory, the attorney general is subject to censure or impeachment by Congress. In reality, given the ideologically diverse Democratic majority in the House and the Republicans' control of the Senate, the chances of that happening are unlikely.
-- Maggie Haberman
I would like to know if the special counsel's team was asked, ordered or pressured to complete the investigation within a certain time frame. If they had more time, say, to issue a grand jury subpoena to obtain the president's testimony, would investigators have been better positioned to make a prosecutorial judgment on obstruction of justice?
Liz Mazucci, Hoboken, N.J.
We don't know of any directives that the Justice Department gave to the Mueller team about the timing of the investigation's completion. But as it pushed into 2019, the special counsel's investigation risked bumping into the start of the president's re-election campaign.
It's worth noting that there are other ongoing federal investigations; the Mueller report says the team made 14 criminal referrals, only two of which are known.
-- Maggie Haberman
______
Obstruction of Justice
Should Americans blame Mueller for his failure to make a concrete deduction on whether Trump obstructed justice? With no substantial deduction, the report will be open to various interpretations across the political divide for the rest of its life.
Musinguzi Blanshe, Kampala, Uganda
Some legal commentators are already making that case.
The result of Mr. Mueller's investigation was not a matter of evidence falling short of the high legal bar needed to indict. Rather, Mr. Mueller said that because the Justice Department's Office of Legal Counsel has declared that sitting presidents cannot be indicted, it would be inappropriate for him to analyze his evidence, lest it "potentially result in a judgment that the president committed crimes." Yet Mr. Mueller also said that if he thought the evidence he gathered had exonerated Mr. Trump, he would have said so.
-- Charlie Savage
What was holding Mueller from the obstruction charge?
Kathryn O'Brien, West Newton, Mass.
Great question. Mr. Mueller made clear that Mr. Trump tried a number of tactics to influence or even sabotage the investigation. But this posed a dilemma because so much of what might be considered obstruction was tied up in Mr. Trump's authority as president, such as firing the F.B.I. director. That executive authority did not give Mr. Trump a free pass, Mr. Mueller said, but it made the prosecutorial calculation different from a typical charging decision.
-- Matt Apuzzo
What was the evidence apparently relied on by Barr and Rosenstein to conclude Trump did not obstruct?
Tom Blinkhorn, Hanover, N.H.
In the summary that Mr. Barr gave Congress a few weeks ago, he said he and Mr. Rosenstein determined there was no obstruction of justice because there was no evidence of a conspiracy between the Trump campaign and Russians. In other words, Mr. Barr said, there was no underlying crime to obstruct.
-- Maggie Haberman
Is Mueller not charging the president with obstruction of justice only because a sitting president cannot be charged, or because there isn't enough evidence? In other words, if this were a civilian being investigated, would they be in handcuffs at this point?
Joyce Harms, Port Washington, Wis.
Mr. Mueller said it would be inappropriate for him to decide whether Mr. Trump committed obstruction of justice, because carrying out that analysis would create the risk of concluding that the president committed a crime. This would be a problem, Mr. Mueller concluded, because the Justice Department holds that the Constitution implicitly prevents sitting presidents from being indicted. He reasoned it would be unfair to accuse Mr. Trump of a crime if the president would have no immediate opportunity to clear his name in a trial.
Notably, however, Mr. Mueller said that if the facts he gathered exonerated Mr. Trump of obstruction, he would have said so.
-- Charlie Savage
Was there any explanation of the president's motives for his actions?
John Brooks, Dallas
The written answers that the president gave to the Mueller team on Nov. 20, 2018, which are appended to the report, address specific actions.
But more broadly, and particularly in the firing of James B. Comey, the former F.B.I. director, the president's lawyers have said over the last two years that Mr. Trump's actions were among broad executive powers afforded to him under Article II of the Constitution.
His advisers have also said Mr. Trump fired Mr. Comey in reaction to investigations of issues related to his presidency since before it began, a sentiment that Mr. Barr echoed in his news briefing on Thursday.
-- Maggie Haberman
______
Trump and Russia
How does Mueller's team reason that the June 2016 Trump Tower meeting with Donald Trump Jr., Jared Kushner, Paul Manafort and the Russian lawyer not constitute an attempted conspiracy, when the whole purpose was to discover dirt on Hillary Clinton?
Danny Weisbaum, Cologne, Germany
This meeting was set up so a Russian lawyer could give politically damaging information about Hillary Clinton to the Trump campaign. Prosecutors analyzed it as a possible violation of federal campaign laws. But Mr. Mueller said he could not prove the campaign officials "knowingly and willfully" intended to commit a crime.
It's also worth noting that investigators found no evidence linking the meeting to the hacking or the release of Mrs. Clinton's emails. Mr. Trump denied knowing about this meeting, and investigators uncovered no evidence that he did.
-- Matt Apuzzo
Will collusion with WikiLeaks continue to be investigated? If the Trump campaign and WikiLeaks knew the information was illegally obtained, isn't it criminal to disseminate that information?
Claire O'Neill, Shrewsbury, Mass.
A fair amount of material about WikiLeaks is redacted, likely because it is related to the ongoing case against Roger Stone, a former adviser to Mr. Trump. So we don't know if Mr. Mueller found evidence of the Trump campaign coordinating with WikiLeaks.
But Mr. Barr said on Thursday that any such coordination could not amount to a criminal conspiracy because WikiLeaks' publication of the stolen material was not a crime unless the group helped Russia steal it.
-- Matt Apuzzo
______
Other Investigations
How much of what was sent to other jurisdictions by Mueller was not included in this report?
Jon Gelberg, North Caldwell, N.J.
Mr. Mueller referred 14 cases to other prosecutors to investigate. We already know about the prosecutions of Michael Cohen, Mr. Trump's former lawyer and fixer, and Gregory B. Craig, who was the White House counsel under President Barack Obama and is charged with lying in a lobbying investigation that grew out of the special counsel inquiry.
The remaining 12 cases are still secret. Details of those cases were redacted but were not given much real estate in the report. We will probably see more charges trickle out over time, but Mr. Mueller said he only referred cases that were unrelated to the key issues in this investigation: Russian interference, the 2016 campaign and obstruction of justice.
-- Matt Apuzzo
Since Barr rejects the idea of pursuing an obstruction-of-justice charge against President Trump, can a different prosecutor (perhaps at the state level) elect to file those charges? Does Barr get the final say?
Mohit Sethi, Ottawa
For now, yes, Mr. Barr has the final say on whether to bring federal charges against Mr. Trump. But Mr. Mueller's rationale for not pursuing obstruction charges leaves the door open to the possibility that after the president leaves office, prosecutors could re-examine the evidence that the special counsel gathered and charge Mr. Trump.
-- Charlie Savage and Michael S. Schmidt
What follows if congressional Democrats decide that Trump's conduct constitutes obstruction, contradicting Barr's conclusion?
Ahir Verma, Green Brook, N.J.
Democrats who control the House are preparing to treat Mr. Mueller's report as a de facto referral for Congress to issue a judgment about the extent, if any, the president and his associates should be held accountable. The House is already investigating whether the president obstructed justice or abused his power. For now, Mr. Mueller's findings will be included in that investigation. But Democrats who have the power to impeach Mr. Trump will soon face a decision about whether there is political support to do so, and put the president on trial in the Republican-controlled Senate.
-- Nicholas Fandos
______
What Comes Next
What does this bode for Trump? What happens next?
Sarah Chan, Singapore
Congress will continue its investigations, and there will be efforts by the Democrat-controlled House to obtain an unredacted version of Mr. Mueller's report. There are also separate but ongoing federal investigations related to, or stemming from, Mr. Mueller's inquiry.
The president's advisers have acknowledged privately that earlier reporting on revelations that were considered potential acts of obstruction of justice helped desensitize people before the report's publication. The advisers believe that helped Mr. Trump.
-- Maggie Haberman
Will the Democrats in Congress get an unredacted version of the report?
Caroline Petti, Washington
We don't know yet. In the near term, Democrat and Republican lawmakers are likely to have private access to a fuller version of the report that includes classified information and material that could harm an ongoing investigation -- content that was blacked out in the public document.
But lawmakers will likely face a fight, and potentially a long one, to view secretive grand jury material that was collected by investigators and included in the report. It is generally illegal to release grand jury information, and to do so for Congress would almost certainly require court approval.
-- Nicholas Fandos
What is the likelihood that Mueller will testify in open session before Congress? And if he does, will he have to steer clear of issues that Barr redacted?
Skip Heaps, Atlanta
A high-stakes, nationally televised hearing with Mr. Mueller appears increasingly likely. Two Democrats who chair House committees on Thursday invited the special counsel to testify, and Mr. Barr, who has a say over whether or not Mr. Mueller can accept, indicated that he would not stand in the way. How expansive Mr. Mueller is willing to be -- or is allowed to be beyond the details of his report -- remains to be seen.
-- Nicholas Fandos
Though not technically "criminal," isn't this activity -- the threats, the firing, the WikiLeaks collusion, the half-billion-dollar Trump Tower Moscow denials during the campaign -- impeachable? Isn't that the real intent of Mueller's position -- that a sitting president cannot be indicted anyway, so it all comes down to impeachment?
Randall Walker, Rochester, Minn.
While it's the Justice Department's policy that presidents can't be indicted, Mr. Mueller would almost surely dispute the notion that he is simply handing an impeachment road map to Congress. Mr. Mueller was tasked with investigating Russian interference and possible coordination with the Trump campaign. Many Russians and campaign officials have been charged.
Impeachment is a political issue, though. Having covered Mr. Mueller as F.B.I. director, I am pretty confident he would say that he did his job and will leave the political questions to the politicians.
-- Matt Apuzzo
______
Media Coverage
It would be interesting to know how many New York Times staff members have been dedicated to reading through the 400+ pages.
Steve Kay, Ohio
We had at least a dozen people dedicated to reading through the report for our stories and briefing. I'm confident the number was even larger than that throughout the day.
-- Maggie Haberman
Is there anything in this report that wasn't already known or reported by the press?
Susan Jonas, Wilmington, Del.
There is a fair amount of new information, particularly details of what Mr. Mueller learned during the course of the probe into whether Mr. Trump obstructed justice.
-- Maggie Haberman
______

Don Lutz, teacher who cultivated Marathon's nature center, dies

Autor: Uhlig, Keith. 

Información de publicación: Wausau Daily Herald ; Wausau, Wis. [Wausau, Wis]. 19 Apr 2019: E.5.

https://www.proquest.com/newspapers/don-lutz-teacher-who-cultivated-marathons-nature/docview/2214140906/se-2?accountid=14708

Resumen: Ninguno disponible.

Enlaces: https://upfinder.upf.edu/openurl/34CSUC_UPF/34CSUC_UPF:VU1?genre=article&amp;atitle=Don+Lutz%2C+teacher+who+cultivated+Marathon%27s+nature+center%2C+dies&amp;author=Uhlig%2C+Keith&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;spage=E.5&amp;date=2019-04-19&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.jtitle=Wausau+Daily+Herald&amp;issn=&amp;isbn=&amp;sid=ProQ%3Amidwestnews1_

Texto completo: MARATHON - Friends, family members and colleagues are remembering science educator Don Lutz as the developer of the Christa McAuliffe Nature Center in Marathon, a teacher's teacher and a lifelong learner himself.
Lutz, a Stevens Point native and 1970 graduate of Pacelli Catholic High School, died April 9 at a hospital in Fort Myers, Florida, as a result of a head injury he sustained in a fall a few days earlier. He was 68.
For most of his career, Lutz was a science teacher for the Marathon Middle School, now the Marathon Venture Academy.
In the late 1980s, when the building for the middle and elementary school was being planned and built, Lutz saw the potential for an undeveloped area on the southern part of the property as an outdoor classroom and nature center.
"I thought for kids nowadays, with all the problems with the environment, that they need to know how a community works," Lutz told the Wausau Daily Herald in 2015 when the center marked its 25th anniversary. "And this pond is a community of animals and plants and populations of different things. So it makes it real easy to adapt that thought to what's happening in the real world."
Money, as it always is for schools, was tight, and there was no budget for the outside learning center. So Lutz took it upon himself to find grant money to pay for its initial development, and secured funding from a foundation named after Christa McAuliffe, a teacher who was one of seven crew members who died in the Space Shuttle Challenger disaster in 1986.
But no matter where he was, Lutz simply loved teaching. He was known for starting his classes each day with a joke, usually science related and usually corny. He was president of the Wisconsin Society of Science Teachers, and he reveled in attending conferences where he could learn how to be a better teacher, but also mentor others who shared his passion.
David Ley, a veteran science teacher for Mosinee High School, met Lutz at such a workshop offered by the Wisconsin Academy Staff Development Initiative. Lutz was the oldest teacher in the group, Ley said, but he brought energy and enthusiasm to the training.
"Don could be a very serious professional, but he was always laughing about something. He always had a joke," Ley said. "He was a lover of the environment and for teaching kids. That was catching, inspiring. ... I think one of the themes of Don's life was that Don didn't just teach a classroom full of kids. He influenced so many educators around the whole state."
In the summers, Lutz led Marathon School District's summer program, teaching courses such as environmental education, rocketry and outdoor skills. Even after he retired as a classroom teacher in 2007, he continued those efforts.
Jenny Baeseman is a 1994 graduate of Marathon High School and a top-level scientist and researcher. Now a consultant, she was the executive director of the Scientific Committee on Antarctic Research, an organization that helps coordinate scientific efforts in Antarctica. She didn't have Lutz as a classroom teacher, but she learned from him in summer programs.
"I remember trying to learn how to read a compass from Mr. Lutz, but for the life of me I couldn't figure it out," Baeseman said in a Facebook message. "I still think of him when I try to use a compass."
Baeseman said Lutz helped inspire "so many people to go into science as a career. But more importantly, he made science fun, which made students learn whether they 'liked science' or not."
Lutz also was an athlete. As a youth, he was on the junior Olympic team for ski jumping, and was also a marathoner, a triathlete and cross-country skier. Joint problems forced him to give up running as he got older, but he still loved walking with his two dogs, Buddy and Charlie, said his wife, Alvie Lutz. The couple had no children.
In recent years, the couple spent most of their winters in Florida, Alvie Lutz wrote in an email message about her husband.
Even though he was retired, he never gave up teaching. He was a substitute teacher for several districts in central Wisconsin, and was thinking about becoming one in Florida.
Nor did he ever stop learning.
"When he was in Florida, he would walk every day to the Fort Myers library and read the complete New York Times," said Dennis DeNuccio, who was a friend of Lutz's since they went to high school together. "And he always has some books piled up on his nightstand. ... I think he just liked to learn."
Contact Keith Uhlig at 715-845-0651 or kuhlig@gannett.com. Follow him at @UhligK on Twitter and Instagram or on Facebook.
CREDIT: Keith Uhlig
