For a growing number of Americans, socialism is OK

Autor: Horseman, Jeff. 

Información de publicación: Daily Breeze ; Torrance, Calif. [Torrance, Calif]. 11 Mar 2019.

https://www.proquest.com/newspapers/growing-number-americans-socialism-is-ok/docview/2190184282/se-2?accountid=14708

Resumen: Ninguno disponible.

Enlaces: https://upfinder.upf.edu/openurl/34CSUC_UPF/34CSUC_UPF:VU1?genre=article&amp;atitle=For+a+growing+number+of+Americans%2C+socialism+is+OK&amp;author=Horseman%2C+Jeff&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;spage=&amp;date=2019-03-11&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.jtitle=Daily+Breeze&amp;issn=&amp;isbn=&amp;sid=ProQ%3Awestnews_

Texto completo: You wouldn’t expect democratic socialists to hit the brakes when it comes to social justice.
But in late February members of Inland Empire Democratic Socialists of America learned how to fix brake lights so they could offer that bit of auto repair service, for free, at an upcoming community event. Working tail lights, they reasoned, would mean fewer police traffic stops and, possibly, fewer fatal outcomes for people of color.
Auto repair is just one part of the chapter’s public outreach about an ideology that, increasingly, is finding a more receptive public audience. Polling shows more Americans, especially Democrats, view socialism more favorably than capitalism, even if they have sometimes wildly different ideas of what socialism is.
“It just doesn’t have the same stigma,” Kimberley Coles, a political anthropologist at the University of Redlands, said of the word “socialism.”
“It doesn’t mean there won’t be … rhetoric and seeing what sticks in terms of the insults.”
A Gallup poll from last summer found that for the first time in 10 years, Democrats had a more positive view of socialism (57 percent) than they did of capitalism (45 percent). That shift among Democrats drove down the overall view of capitalism.
“A majority of Americans have retained a positive view of capitalism over the past eight years, but this year’s 56% positive rating is by four points the lowest recorded since 2010,” Gallup reported. “Americans’ positive views of socialism have varied only between 35% and 39%, with (2018’s) reading of 37% right at the trend average.”
Gallup also found that among young people (ages 18 to 29) capitalism had slipped from 68 percent approval in 2010 to 45 percent approval last year.
Gallup isn’t the only pollster seeing that trend.
Thirty-one percent of Democrats in a YouGov poll from last August said they would be “comfortable” with a socialist presidential candidate, compared to just 8 percent for Republicans.
The same YouGov poll found 44 percent of Americans had a favorable view of capitalism, down from 52 percent in 2015. Americans age 18 through 29 are likelier to see the word “socialist” as a compliment while Americans age 65 and older are more likely to consider it an insult, although the 65-and-up group views socialism more favorably now (25 percent) than in 2015 (15 percent), according to YouGov.
Capitalism’s polling dip — and the corresponding rise in approval for the label “socialism” — coincides with ballot box gains by politicians who are connected with the political organization Democratic Socialists of America.
Running as Democrats, Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez and Rashida Tlaib in 2018 became the first Democratic Socialists of America members to win congressional seats. Democratic Socialist Bernie Sanders’ stronger-than-expected 2016 presidential campaign fueled an effort to turn the Democratic Party leftward, a trend that’s continued with Ocasio-Cortez’s celebrity status.
Nationally, Democratic Socialists of America had just 5,000 members prior to November 2016, but passed the 40,000-member mark following Ocasio-Cortez’s upset in New York’s June 2018 primary, according to published reports.
The organization’s Southern California connections include chapters in the Inland Empire, Orange County and Los Angeles. “Our chapter is continuing to grow and evolve from its humble roots,” the Inland chapter collectively wrote in response to emailed questions. “Fresh faces appear at every monthly member meeting.”
It’s not just about faces and personalities, either.
Ocasio-Cortez’s proposal for a Green New Deal, along with proposals from many candidates for universal health care, higher taxes on the rich and other socialist-favored ideas, figure to loom over the crowded race for the 2020 Democratic presidential nomination.
It’s also already become a rallying cry — perhaps even the central theme — of Republican election efforts.
During last month’s State of the Union address, President Donald Trump drew applause from supporters when he invoked socialism as a pejorative.
“We are alarmed by new calls to adopt socialism in our country,” he said before declaring that “America will never be a socialist country.”
Fears of socialism “could become the kind of rhetorical touchstone of (President Trump’s 2020) campaign that sounding the alarm about ‘criminal illegal aliens’ was in 2016,” The New York Times reported.
“Socialism is the greatest vulnerability by far that the House Democrats have,” Rep. Tom Emmer of Minnesota, who chairs the National Republican Congressional Committee, told the Times.
Socialism replaced Hillary Clinton as the main villain at this year’s Conservative Political Action Conference, which featured a “bread line” mocking Ocasio-Cortez.
“They want to take away your hamburgers,” former White House adviser Sebastian Gorka warned conference-goers. “This is what Stalin dreamed about but never achieved.”
What is socialism?
Americans fight not only over whether socialism is good or bad, but over what it means. Seventeen percent defined socialism as “government ownership of the means of production,” that was about half the number of Americans who used that definition of socialism in 1949, Gallup reported last October.
“Americans today are most likely to define socialism as connoting equality for everyone, while others understand the term as meaning the provision of benefits and social services, a modified form of communism, or a conception of socialism as people being social and getting along with one another About a quarter of Americans were not able to give an answer.”
The Democratic Socialists of America is “a ‘big tent’ organization,” the Inland chapter said. “Members may embrace a variety of tactics, theoretical frameworks, and emphases, but ultimately work toward a classless society undergirded by an economy in which production and the fruits of production are shared by all.”
To fight what the chapter sees as misconceptions – socialism is “inherently totalitarian” or a “mere matter of welfare state programs,” for example – members stress that socialism is organized from the bottom-up, outside of government, and that socialism emphasizes freedom, including “the ability of working people to resist the private tyranny of the firm and its owners,” the chapter said.
Socialism made Sanders and Ocasio-Cortez, not the other way around, the chapter said. “Their ideas were popular because the moment was right for a socialist alternative, after a major recession, stagnant wages, and widespread discontent with the status quo.
“Our chapter as a whole is sympathetic to Bernie/AOC, but we seek also to hold them accountable to their promises, and members may find that their views do not completely overlap with theirs. This being said, among elected officials, their reform agenda is the closest in spirit to our movement …”
Besides fixing brake lights, the Inland chapter, which estimates it has 30 to 40 active members, also stumps for Medicare-for-all at events like Riverside’s monthly Public Arts Walk. It also hosts movie screenings with discussions afterward – “Sorry to Bother You” was a recent feature – and members have traveled to Mexico to help migrants at the border.
“A new idea”
Coles and Harold Clarke, a political science professor at the University of Texas at Dallas, think socialism’s surging popularity, especially among millennials, is rooted in recent history.
“Socialism’s kind of a new idea for them and it’s detached from a lot of the economics and brutal politics of the past,” Clarke said.
Millennials “aren’t shaped by Cold War politics, much less attachment to political parties,” Coles said. “They’re interested in a la carte political ideas, rather than being labeled as Republicans or socialist.”
They also grew up during the Great Recession of the late 2000s, when capitalism’s flaws “were highlighted in political rhetoric,” Coles added. “Socialism has historically always offered a critique of capitalism and highlighted the inequality of economic and political power.”
The Trump backlash also might be a factor. “With his hotel empire, numerous side businesses, and history of shortchanging employees and contractors, current President Donald Trump perhaps encapsulates capitalism at its worst … ,” Eillie Anzilotti wrote in an article about the Gallup poll results for Fast Company magazine.
She added that Trump alone likely doesn’t explain the drop in capitalism’s popularity, especially among young people. “Since the 1970s, wages (adjusted for inflation) have barely risen, while (the) cost of living has skyrocketed across the U.S. Meanwhile, the top 1% of earners in America … has captured 85% of income growth that’s occurred since 2009.”
The uptick in socialism’s popularity could be a lasting trend, Coles said.
“I feel that these millennial voters are … more interested in learning from others (and are more) cosmopolitan in being willing to take ideas from lots of places,” she said. “It seems that people are interested in new ideas and socialism is offering one set of solutions.”

NEW YORK TIMES WRITES ARCHITECT JULIA MORGAN'S OBIT 62 YEARS LATER

Autor: Zavoral, Linda. 

Información de publicación: The Mercury News ; San Jose, Calif. [San Jose, Calif]. 11 Mar 2019: B.7.

https://www.proquest.com/newspapers/new-york-times-writes-architect-julia-morgans/docview/2190066930/se-2?accountid=14708

Resumen: Ninguno disponible.

Enlaces: https://upfinder.upf.edu/openurl/34CSUC_UPF/34CSUC_UPF:VU1?genre=article&amp;atitle=NEW+YORK+TIMES+WRITES+ARCHITECT+JULIA+MORGAN%27S+OBIT+62+YEARS+LATER&amp;author=Zavoral%2C+Linda&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;spage=B.7&amp;date=2019-03-11&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.jtitle=The+Mercury+News&amp;issn=&amp;isbn=&amp;sid=ProQ%3Awestnews_

Texto completo: Looking back, the first Saturday of February in 1957 was a newsy day on the international front, but not much was happening around this country. According to OnThisDay.com, the United Nations adopted a resolution calling for Israeli troops to leave Egypt. And the play "Candide" closed in New York after just 73 performances.
But somehow, the New York Times managed to overlook the death of one of the country's most famous architects, Julia Morgan, the designer of the legendary Hearst Castle.
Last week, the newspaper of record made amends for that oversight.
As part of its "Overlooked No More" series, the paper published an extensive obituary feature on Morgan 62 years after her Feb. 2, 1957, death in San Francisco.
The introduction reads: "Since 1851, obituaries in The New York Times have been dominated by white men. With Overlooked,' we're adding the stories of remarkable people whose deaths went unreported in The Times."
The article by Alexandra Lange chronicles Morgan's life and career, from her birth in San Francisco and upbringing in Oakland to her civil engineering studies with Bernard Maybeck at UC Berkeley and the challenges she faced as a pioneering architect.
"As the first woman to receive an architect's license in California, in 1904, Morgan early on was used to skepticism about her abilities," the article says. "But she came to allay those doubts by building a sterling reputation with projects now known around the world, including the Asilomar conference grounds on the Monterey Peninsula and, most notably, the Hearst Castle at San Simeon. By the time she retired in 1951, at 79, she had designed hundreds of buildings and sites."
One early challenge came after the 1906 earthquake left the Fairmont Hotel in ruins just days before its opening. The owners hired Morgan, based partly on her success with an earlier project in Oakland.
"Only three years earlier she had built a bell tower on the campus of Mills College, and it had withstood the earthquake unscathed proof that Morgan was as experienced in reinforced concrete as she was in European design," Lange wrote.
But skepticism about her work persisted, and the San Francisco Call sent reporter Jane Armstrong over to the building site in 1907 to talk with the foreman.
Lange quoted the Call article: "Yes, the foreman answered, it was in the charge of a real architect, and her name happens to be Julia Morgan, but it might as well be John Morgan.'"
A decade later, Morgan was designing buildings at Asilomar for Phoebe Apperson Hearst, when she undertook the commission of her career, the Hearst Castle project with William Randolph Hearst, which would last 25 years.
Besides those landmark projects on the Central Coast, she notably designed the Berkeley City Club, San Francisco's Chinatown YWCA and hundreds of other buildings. In the South Bay, a piece of her legacy is currently on the market. The 1910 home-turned-office, located at 1650 The Alameda in San Jose, has been listed for $3.4 million by Cushman & Wakefield.
So why did the Times fail to write about her death? "In the 1950s, the emphasis was on the new, the modern, and the heroic not to mention on architecture to house the masses," Lange wrote. "Morgan was largely forgotten."
Thanks to the efforts of biographer Sara Holmes Boutelle and other architects, Morgan's "reputation was restored" years after her death, the obituary says. In 2014, she was posthumously awarded the American Institute of Architects Gold Medal a first for a woman.
Morgan is buried with other California luminaries at Mountain View Cemetery in Oakland.
CREDIT: By Linda Zavoral, lzavoral@bayareanewsgroup.com

Trump Administration could use social media to cut down on federal disability fraud

Autor: Tomasic, Megan. 

Información de publicación: Tribune - Review / Pittsburgh Tribune - Review ; Greensburg, Pa. [Greensburg, Pa]. 11 Mar 2019.

https://www.proquest.com/newspapers/trump-administration-could-use-social-media-cut/docview/2189941126/se-2?accountid=14708

Resumen: Ninguno disponible.

Enlaces: https://upfinder.upf.edu/openurl/34CSUC_UPF/34CSUC_UPF:VU1?genre=article&amp;atitle=Trump+Administration+could+use+social+media+to+cut+down+on+federal+disability+fraud&amp;author=Tomasic%2C+Megan&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;spage=&amp;date=2019-03-11&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.jtitle=Tribune+-+Review+%2F+Pittsburgh+Tribune+-+Review&amp;issn=&amp;isbn=&amp;sid=ProQ%3Anortheastnews1_

Texto completo: Federal disability recipients may want to watch what they post on social media.
The Trump administration could soon use websites like Facebook and Twitter to help find people who claim Social Security disability benefits who are not actually disabled, The New York Times reported.
About 10 percent of Westmoreland County residents under the age of 65 identified as having a disability between 2013 and 2017, according to the Census Bureau. Between the same years, 9 percent of Allegheny County residents under the age of 65 identified as having a disability.
The number of people receiving disability benefits in both counties was not immediately available Monday.
According to the report, social media would be used to identify fraud and to increase the integrity of the program.
The New York Times said administration officials have been working on the proposal with Social Security, calling social media a possible "treasure trove of information" about people applying for benefits.
On Monday, President Trump announced a $4.75 trillion budget proposal, The New York Times reported, proposing to spend "$26 billion less on Social Security programs, including a $10 billion cut on the Social Security Disability Insurance program."
To apply for disability benefits, a Social Security number must be provided for the applicant, spouses and any kids, along with a routing number from a bank.
Information about the applicants medical condition like dates of treatment for all doctors, hospitals and clinics; names of medications taken and the name of the doctor who prescribed them; and the names and dates of all medical tests done much be provided in the application.
Trump also proposed new work requirements for recipients of federal housing support, food stamps and Medicaid, which could reduce spending by $327 billion on the programs over a decade, according to the newspaper.
About 41,000 people in Westmoreland County and 148,000 people in Allegheny County receive benefits from the Supplemental Nutrition Assistant Program, also called food stamps, according to December state figures.
CREDIT: by MEGAN TOMASIC

SXSW Sports: Bleacher Report hopes to keep expanding reach over sports market

Autor: Jones, Thomas. 

Información de publicación: Austin American Statesman ; Austin, Tex. [Austin, Tex]. 11 Mar 2019: 8.

https://www.proquest.com/newspapers/sxsw-sports-bleacher-report-hopes-keep-expanding/docview/2189502744/se-2?accountid=14708

Resumen: Ninguno disponible.

Enlaces: https://upfinder.upf.edu/openurl/34CSUC_UPF/34CSUC_UPF:VU1?genre=article&amp;atitle=SXSW+Sports%3A+Bleacher+Report+hopes+to+keep+expanding+reach+over+sports+market&amp;author=Jones%2C+Thomas&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;spage=8&amp;date=2019-03-11&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.jtitle=Austin+American+Statesman&amp;issn=&amp;isbn=&amp;sid=ProQ%3Asouthcentralnews_

Texto completo: What makes the American sports fan tick?
Bleacher Report certainly knows. At least that’s the message delivered Sunday during the South by Southwest interactive festival in downtown Austin by Bleacher Report’s Ed Romaine, who serves — wait for it — as the company’s chief branding officer.
Romaine spent his allotted 45 minutes at a panel entitled “The Heart of the American Sports Fan” explaining how Bleacher Report’s mix of social engagement, rapid-fire updates, live feeds and expanding attention to betting has helped the company grow from a startup in a San Francisco basement 10 years ago to an international media force valued in the multi-millions.
“To us, it’s more about what the fans think of the game than what some TV anchor says the next day,” said Romaine, appropriately dressed in retro Stan Smiths and skinny black jeans befitting his target demographic of Premier League-watching millennials and Gen Zers.
And Romaine came with the slideshow to prove it.
The gospel, according to Bleacher Report: Ninety-six percent of its Instagram followers are using another device while watching live sports; 63 percent of its followers are using Instagram while watching live sports; and there were 1.3 billion social video views across what Romain referred to as “Bleacher Report’s ecosystem.”
The success of Bleacher Report in a market saturated with sports can’t be ignored. The company, owned by Turner Sports, is now ubiquitous, as evident by everything from their sponsorship of Champions League broadcasts in the U.S. to the notifications that ping on the coworker’s phone two cubicles over.
As the New York Times pointed out in a recent article, Bleacher Report’s House of Highlights — an Instagram account that the company bought from a college student in Florida a few years ago — has 12 million followers.
But Bleacher Report wants to be all things to everyone. Romaine pointed out that gambling content has the highest growth rate of followers among BR’s youngest audience, but he also says “we’re mindful of how we promote it, especially to a younger audience.” He shows snippets of videos the company has produced with Carmelo Anthony, who apparently has plenty of time on his hands between occasional stints with NBA teams. He says long-form narrative is important, but “we don’t want to lose anyone who just wants scores.”
“How are we drawing consumers into our ethos and identity?” Romaine asked the listeners inside the JW Marriott hotel.
But what exactly is that identity for Bleacher Report 10 years into its existence? Perhaps that’s a question Romaine and other executives will have to answer soon.

Sanders, Biden are favorites of likely Iowa caucusgoers

Información de publicación: Boston Globe ; Boston, Mass. [Boston, Mass]. 11 Mar 2019: A.10.

https://www.proquest.com/newspapers/sanders-biden-are-favorites-likely-iowa/docview/2189398851/se-2?accountid=14708

Resumen: Ninguno disponible.

Enlaces: https://upfinder.upf.edu/openurl/34CSUC_UPF/34CSUC_UPF:VU1?genre=article&amp;atitle=Sanders%2C+Biden+are+favorites+of+likely+Iowa+caucusgoers&amp;author=&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;spage=A.10&amp;date=2019-03-11&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.jtitle=Boston+Globe&amp;issn=0743-1791&amp;isbn=&amp;sid=ProQ%3Anortheastnews1_

Texto completo: Former vice president Joe Biden and Senator Bernie Sanders lead a new poll of likely Iowa caucusgoers released this weekend, underscoring how the nomination process for the Democratic Party has, to this early point, been defined by the two figures with the largest national profiles.
The poll, which was conducted by The Des Moines Register and CNN, had Biden as the top choice for 27 percent of respondents, leading all candidates. Though Biden's advisers have signaled that he intends to run for president, he has yet to announce his candidacy. Sanders, who kicked off his campaign recently in New York City, was the top choice for 25 percent of those asked.
Poll numbers have fallen sharply, however, for the other major holdout: former US representative Beto O'Rourke, who lost a Senate bid in Texas in 2018 and could announce his candidacy in the coming weeks. Only 5 percent of likely caucusgoers now call him their first choice for president, down from 11 percent in December.
The Iowa caucuses will be held in early February 2020.
The next closest figure to Biden and Sanders, according to the poll, was Senator Elizabeth Warren of Massachusetts, who was among the first to announce her presidential candidacy. Warren was the top choice for 9 percent of respondents, followed by Senator Kamala Harris of California, who was favored by 7 percent of respondents and had soaring favorability ratings.
Other candidates — including Senators Cory Booker of New Jersey, Kirsten Gillibrand of New York, and Amy Klobuchar of Minnesota — have struggled to make an imprint, the poll found.
New York Times
Cheney blasts Trump plan that allies pay for US troops
A top Republican blasted the Trump administration's potential demand that countries pay the full cost of hosting US troops and then some, saying it's a "wrongheaded" move that would jeopardize both national security and relationships with allies.
"It would be absolutely devastating," Representative Liz Cheney of Wyoming, who heads the House Republican Conference and serves on the Armed Services Committee, said Sunday on NBC's "Meet the Press."
Cheney was responding to a Bloomberg News report on Friday that the administration is developing so-called "cost plus 50" plans to force countries to pay the full price of American soldiers deployed on their soil, plus an additional 50 percent or more for the privilege. Nations hosting American forces could see their tab climb five to six times their current costs.
"We benefit tremendously" by stationing soldiers in South Korea, Japan, Germany, and other countries, Cheney said. "The notion that we are now going to somehow charge them 'cost plus 50' is really — it's wrongheaded, and it would be devastating to the security of the nation and our allies."
Trump's planned proposal is in line with his efforts to encourage US allies to boost their defense spending. But it has stoked concerns among diplomats and security experts who fear any "cost plus 50" demand would be an affront to allies in Asia and Europe who already question the depth of Trump's commitment to them.
Cheney vowed to oppose the move in Congress. Asked whether fellow Republicans would join her in rejecting the plan, given their tendency to acquiesce to the president on most matters, she said politicians must be aware of the security dividends the United States gets from having troops stationed abroad.
"It's going to be very important for us to make sure that people understand the danger that that will do to our relationships and to our fundamental security," Cheney said.
Bloomberg News
'The ISIS threat will remain,' John Bolton says
National security adviser John Bolton said Sunday that the Islamic State remains a threat and that it is "growing in other parts of the world" besides Syria and Iraq.
The statement by Bolton in an interview on ABC News' "This Week" is at odds with claims by President Trump and Vice President Mike Pence late last year that the militant group, which is also known as ISIS, has been defeated.
"The president has been, I think, as clear as clear can be, when he talks about the defeat of the ISIS territorial caliphate," Bolton said. "He has never said that the elimination of the territorial caliphate means the end of ISIS in total. We know that's not the case."
He added that Islamic State fighters are "scattered still around Syria and Iraq, and that ISIS itself is growing in other parts of the world. The ISIS threat will remain."
The White House has delivered mixed messages on the matter.
Friday night, at an outdoor fund-raiser at his Mar-a-Lago club in Palm Beach, Fla., Trump said the caliphate was 100 percent destroyed, according to an attendee.
In a December tweet, Trump announced that the United States was withdrawing from Syria, declaring, "We have defeated ISIS in Syria, my only reason for being there during the Trump Presidency." Trump appeared to slightly shift course later that month, stating on Twitter that the extremist group is "mostly gone." He has since agreed to maintain a presence of about 400 troops in Syria.
Pence, meanwhile, said in a speech at the State Department in January that "the caliphate has crumbled, and ISIS has been defeated."
Bolton was responding to a statement by General Joseph Votel, the commander of US forces in the Middle East, who said at a House Armed Services Committee hearing last week that the fight against the Islamic State "is far from over."
Bolton said Sunday that he is "very optimistic" that US allies such as Britain and France will help in battling the resurgence of the group.
Washington Post
Schiff says Mueller should be interviewing Trump
The chairman of the House Intelligence Committee said Sunday that Special Counsel Robert Mueller was making a "mistake" by not demanding that President Trump testify as part of his investigation, which by many accounts may soon be nearing its end.
Speaking on NBC's "Meet the Press," Representative Adam Schiff, a California Democrat, acknowledged that it might be expedient for Mueller to avoid subpoenaing Trump's testimony because the president could fight it and Mueller's new boss, Attorney General William Barr, might oppose such a move.
"But I do think ultimately it's a mistake, because probably the best way to get the truth would be to put the president under oath," Schiff said. "As he's made plain in the past, he feels it's perfectly fine to lie to the public. After all, he has said, 'It's not like I'm talking before a magistrate.' Well, maybe he should talk before a magistrate."
Schiff also said he is deferring to Mueller on whether Erik Prince, a former Navy SEAL who created the controversial Blackwater security company, lied to Congress about his involvement in the Trump campaign.
The House Intelligence Committee spoke with Prince in 2017 about his meeting in January that year with Kirill Dmitriev, head of the Russian Direct Investment Fund; the meeting in question was organized by the United Arab Emirates in the Seychelles. Prince presented the meeting to congressional investigators as a series of coincidences and insisted to the committee that he played no role in Trump's campaign or transition team.
But it is an August 2016 meeting in Trump Tower, which Prince admitted to participating in during an interview with Al Jazeera last week but never disclosed to the Intelligence Committee, that has revived suspicions that Prince lied to Congress under penalty of perjury.
In the Al Jazeera interview, Prince insists that he disclosed the August meeting to investigators, despite no mention of it in the public transcript, something Prince explained by suggesting the transcript must be wrong.
"He's certainly not telling the truth in that interview," Schiff said.
Washington Post

Got the job? Don't stop being curious, engaged

Información de publicación: Detroit Free Press ; Detroit, Mich. [Detroit, Mich]. 10 Mar 2019: B.2.

https://www.proquest.com/newspapers/got-job-dont-stop-being-curious-engaged/docview/2189275451/se-2?accountid=14708

Resumen: Ninguno disponible.

Enlaces: https://upfinder.upf.edu/openurl/34CSUC_UPF/34CSUC_UPF:VU1?genre=article&amp;atitle=Got+the+job%3F+Don%27t+stop+being+curious%2C+engaged&amp;author=&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;spage=B.2&amp;date=2019-03-10&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.jtitle=Detroit+Free+Press&amp;issn=&amp;isbn=&amp;sid=ProQ%3Amidwestnews1_

Texto completo: You hardly slept the night before and arrived to the meeting 25 minutes early. You were wearing your favorite outfit and were fully prepared to put your best foot forward. No, I'm not talking about your first date, but rather that job interview that landed you your gig.
Think about how you were fully present, asked thoughtful questions, and did everything you could to shine. Realizing the importance of the meeting, you went above and beyond to demonstrate your value and position yourself as a linchpin.
The problem for many of us is that we significantly reduce our efforts once the job is ours. Yet if you really think about you, you're always interviewing.
The way you perform in a meeting will establish how colleagues view you. If you under-deliver for a client, your reputation for mediocrity spreads. When you mail it in thinking no one will notice, frankly everyone notices.
On the other hand, each touch point with others is an interview opportunity. Those who regularly demonstrate the same professionalism, intensity, curiosity and focus they exhibited during their interview are the ones who achieve greatly. While daily interactions lack the formality of a job interview, isn't our responsibility to perform just the same?
When a musician, actor, or dancer auditions, he or she is committed to showcasing their best work. After the audition, the ones who continue to view every performance a new audition for future possibilities are the ones who make history, while the ones that get caught in the daily grind are the ones whose careers eventually get ground up and spit out.
Whatever your craft may be — from delivering keynote speeches to selling insurance —each time you take the proverbial stage should be a treasured moment to perform at your best. Even if you have that particular situation in the bag, think of it as an interview to win the next one.
To reinforce your passion and focus, so that your value is undeniable. While we can't prepare as many hours as we did for the big job interview, we must make sure we bring the same intensity and commitment to putting our best foot forward on a consistent basis.
Every day is a new interview, even if you've been on the job for 20 years. Each professional interaction is the opportunity to audition for something more, even if it doesn't seem obvious. When we realize that we're always interviewing, we elevate our impact on others, and in turn, we realize our full potential.
Josh Linkner is a tech entrepreneur, New York Times bestselling author and keynote speaker. For information, visit joshlinkner.com.
Josh Linkner
Columnist
Detroit Free Press
USA TODAY NETWORK
Josh Linkner
Columnist
Detroit Free Press
USA TODAY NETWORK

____________________________________________________________

A war of words over 'enemy of the people'

Autor: Montini, Ed. 

Información de publicación: Arizona Republic ; Phoenix, Ariz. [Phoenix, Ariz]. 10 Mar 2019: D.5.

https://www.proquest.com/newspapers/war-words-over-enemy-people/docview/2189263918/se-2?accountid=14708

Resumen: Ninguno disponible.

Enlaces: https://upfinder.upf.edu/openurl/34CSUC_UPF/34CSUC_UPF:VU1?genre=unknown&amp;atitle=A+war+of+words+over+%27enemy+of+the+people%27&amp;author=Montini%2C+Ed&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;spage=D.5&amp;date=2019-03-10&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.jtitle=Arizona+Republic&amp;issn=0892-8711&amp;isbn=&amp;sid=ProQ%3Asouthcentralnews_

Texto completo: Not too long ago a man with a knowing look on his face approached me in the parking lot of a local grocery store and said in a way that was both cordial and ... not, "Did they know in there that they just did business with an enemy of the people? Or did you use one of your aliases."
"Christopher Paul Hasson," I said.
"Who?"
The name didn't ring any bells with the gentleman, who laughed and went on his way.
How about you?
Hasson?
He was in the news briefly last month. Way too briefly if you ask me. (Though no one did.)
However, if Hasson had accomplished what he allegedly set out to accomplish, it's likely we'd ALL know his name. For a little while, anyway. And there's even a chance President Donald Trump and his most worshipful sycophants would temper their use of the word "enemy" to describe Democrats and members of the news media.
Then again, maybe not.
The language Trump uses trickles down.
For example, the current head of the Arizona Republican Party, Kelli Ward, tweeted during her failed campaign for a U.S. Senate seat:
The #FakeNews media balks at the notion that they're the enemy of the people all while continuing to oppose the #AmericaFirst agenda. If you don't like the moniker, drop the left-wing policies like open borders & sanctuary cities which result in MORE CRIME! ...
In January, Navajo County Republicans elected a man named Mac Rojo as their first vice chair.
Rojo said at the time, "Our domestic enemy is the Democrats."
Not our political adversary.
Not our philosophical opposites.
"Domestic enemy."
Political people like Ward and Rojo feed off Trump, of course. And before long the language of politicians becomes the language of choice in supermarket parking lots.
And it's perpetually reinforced.
After Democrats didn't stand and cheer during the president's State of the Union address Trump said, "They were like death and un-American. Un-American. Somebody said treasonous. Yeah, I guess, why not? Can we call that treason? Why not? I mean, they certainly didn't seem to love our country very much."
Treason?
For not standing?
Trump is relentless about this on twitter. As in:
THE RIGGED AND CORRUPT MEDIA IS THE ENEMY OF THE PEOPLE!
And:
The New York Times reporting is false. They are a true ENEMY OF THE PEOPLE!
The publisher of the Times, A.G. Sulzberger, said, "It is particularly reckless coming from someone whose office gives him broad powers to fight or imprison the nation's enemies. As I have repeatedly told President Trump face to face, there are mounting signs that this incendiary rhetoric is encouraging threats and violence against journalists at home and abroad."
There already has been violence against journalists at home and abroad.
There have been deaths.
And there might have been a lot more if Christopher Paul Hasson hadn't been nabbed before he had the chance to carry out the massacre authorities say he planned.
After the Navajo County Republicans first vice chair said, "Our domestic enemy is the Democrats," the White Mountain Independent printed an op-ed by Sheryl Eaton, chair of the White Mountain Democrats, who wrote in part, "We are not enemies; we are all people who want the best for our country. We just have to work together on how to do what's best."
That's true for elected officials, though it doesn't seem likely, given the language used by some politicians — by the president.
It's dangerous.
Democrats are not the enemy. The media is not the enemy.
I read comment a while back by Washington Post editor Marty Baron that explains the situation simply and precisely.
Commenting on Trump's rhetoric he said, "We're not at war with the administration, we're at work."
Reach Montini at ed.montini@arizonarepublic.com.
CREDIT: Ed Montini

____________________________________________________________

WHY LIBRARIES MATTER ACCORDING TO 8 CONNECTICUT AUTHORS

Información de publicación: Hartford Courant ; Hartford, Conn. [Hartford, Conn]. 10 Mar 2019: C.1.

https://www.proquest.com/newspapers/why-libraries-matter-according-8-connecticut/docview/2189257590/se-2?accountid=14708

Resumen: Ninguno disponible.

Enlaces: https://upfinder.upf.edu/openurl/34CSUC_UPF/34CSUC_UPF:VU1?genre=article&amp;atitle=WHY+LIBRARIES+MATTER+ACCORDING+TO+8+CONNECTICUT+AUTHORS&amp;author=&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;spage=C.1&amp;date=2019-03-10&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.jtitle=Hartford+Courant&amp;issn=1047-4153&amp;isbn=&amp;sid=ProQ%3Anortheastnews1_

Texto completo: Libraries are vital anchors in their communities. As the mission of Hartford Public Library says, libraries "provide free resources that inspire reading, guide learning, and encourage individual exploration." We asked eight Connecticut authors and poets to tell us why libraries matter, from their personal perspective. Here are their stories.
Research, community - and serendipity
By Wally Lamb
Sometime next year, my second novel, "I Know This Much Is True," will air as a six-episode HBO series starring Mark Ruffalo in a double role as troubled identical twins. The story began in 1992 on the fourth floor of UConn's Homer Babbidge Library. I wrote a lot of it in longhand with a Bic pen and a thick folder of loose-leaf pages.
Whenever the story stopped flowing, which often happened, I'd get up from the study carrel I thought of as mine and wander the stacks where, frequently, serendipitous "accidents" happened. When the novel was in its nascent stage, I knew, for instance, that its central characters, Dominick and Thomas Birdsey, were brothers. However, it wasn't until I pulled a book from some miscellaneous shelf and a photocopied essay by anthropologist Claude Levi-Strauss titled "Harelips and Twins" fell out and onto my shoe that it dawned on me that these brothers were identicals. The discovery felt like lightning striking.
It struck a second time when Italian writer Gabriele D'Annunzio's collection of short stories, "Tales of My Native Town," demanded my attention and led me to "I Know This Much Is True's" story-within-the-story about the Birdsey brothers' immigrant grandfather. His voice flowed out of my Bic faster than a rushing river and became the beating heart of the novel.
At the Babbidge Library, research librarians helped me to discover what the weather had been like in Groton on the day in 1954 when first lady Mamie Eisenhower christened the USS Nautilus, what might happen to the insides of an abusive husband whose wife was sneaking ground glass into his food, and what happens to a family when paranoid schizophrenia and sudden infant death syndrome descend. All of the above was woven into the tapestry of the twins' story.
Throughout my writing life, I have relied on libraries for research, solitude, community and serendipity. The springboards for my fiction wait quietly and patiently for me in these gloriously democratic institutions.
Wally Lamb is the author of six novels, including two New York Times No. 1 best-sellers. He is the editor of two nonfiction anthologies, collections of autobiographical essays that evolved from a writing workshop he facilitates at Connecticut's York Correctional Institute, a maximum-security prison for women. A third collection is scheduled for publication in October.
Celebrating libraries
By Kate Rushin

I had been under the impression that "the library" had always been there and would always be there. My first memory of a library book was a thick tome that I would take down from my grandmother's bookcase; I'd sit on the rug, leaf through it and read. The book was the original 1941 hardcover edition of "The Negro Caravan: Writings by American Negros," an anthology of poems, songs, short stories and essays, edited and written by Sterling A. Brown, Ulysses G. LeeJr. and Arnold P. Davis.
Many years passed before I could appreciate the historical significance of the collection or the ink stamp on the inside cover: Property of The Camden Public Library. I did not dream, in long ago South Jersey, that one day I would study poetry with Michael S. Harper, Sterling Brown's friend and editor. Or that professor Harper would lead me to the John Hay Library at Brown University, where I would hold a 19th-century edition of the poetry of Phillis Wheatley in my hands. All I knew, as a kid, was that I loved the book and that it was probably long overdue.
Our neighborhood library branch was a storefront, in walking distance, just off The Avenue. It was there that I checked out "Mary Poppins," "Little Women," "Champion's Choice," "Wind in the Willows," "Little House in the Big Woods," "The Yearling" and joke books. I got quite a jolt when I came home from college to find that "my library" had been closed. The bigger shock came as I drove to downtown to find the old, stately, Main Branch (across from where I had cashiered in the drugstore one summer) boarded up too. The library closings signaled a shift. Something had changed; something was not right in our city.
The library has always been a place for knowledge of other places, other times, other worlds; for me, it has also been a place of refuge, a place for poetry and celebration. My book "The Black Back-Ups" was honored by the New York Public Library at "The Donnell" branch. I've had the opportunity to read at the Schomburg Center for Research in Black Culture in Harlem.
I realize that during my time in Connecticut, I've visited more than two dozen public libraries, whether as a poet, patron, workshop leader, audience member or as a writer looking for just the place to work for a few hours. I'm ever grateful to poet Bessy Reyna for her Hartford Loves Poetry program. I am honored to have been commissioned to write the 125th Anniversary Poem for the Hartford Public Library. Through the life and work of Caroline Hewins, "The First Lady of The Library," I am reminded that libraries weren't always open to everyone; I am reminded of what would be lost if we, as a community, ever take the public library for granted.
Kate Rushin, a poet and educator, is the author of "The Black Back-Ups," a poetry collection. Her work has been widely anthologized. She has served on the James Merrill House committee in Stonington and the poetry advisory committee of the Sunken Garden Poetry Festival at the Hill-Stead Museum in Farmington.
Reading in the stacks: Heaven on earth
By Amy Bloom

I love my local Branford library - the Willoughby Wallace Memorial Library. I love the Blackstone Library, which is its big sister. But the library of my heart and my childhood, the library that is the standard for all libraries great and small, is the Arrandale Public Library of Great Neck, N.Y., and it is no longer.
It was a big building - like a squashed Greek temple. The floors were wood, and there was a treacherous metal spiral staircase to the stacks, where I spent much of my life.
Every Saturday afternoon, my father would drop me off at the library, claiming that he had a haircut, and I would read in the stacks until he came back to get me two or three hours later. This was an arrangement that suited us both entirely and which we never revealed to my mother. I worked my way in fiction from Louis May Alcott to Emile Zola.
The librarians carefully stepped over me as I spread myself out with my red licorice whips, my dirty pink glasses and my saddle shoes on the cool slate floor. It was, for me, heaven on earth.
Amy Bloom is the author of four novels and several collections of short stories. She has been a nominee for both the National Book Award and the National Book Critics Circle Award. Her stories have appeared in "Best American Short Stories," "Prize Stories: The O. Henry Awards," and numerous anthologies. She is Wesleyan University's Shapiro-Silverberg professor of creative writing.
In the land of libraries
By Frederick Douglass Knowles II
My memory of a local library sends me sailing across the waves of my youth back to the shores of Thomas W. Mahan Elementary in Norwich. It was there, beyond the threshold of a quaint four-cornered alcove, where I discovered literary wonderment. A haven of hidden books inspired me to emulate Ms. Fitzgerald's melodic whispers of adventure in reverence.
She read endlessly. The weekly ventures from her kindergarten classroom, down the hall, past the main office, and a slight right after the cafeteria fed my passion for poetry.
Libraries led me to poetry. Poetry to the appointment as poet laureate. Adults encourage children to follow dreams. Though how would they know where to begin without a colossus of words navigating them? There is an astounding treasure in the land of libraries - a treasure that, much like a chest, can only be discovered by cracking the cover of a hidden gem.
Frederick Douglass Knowles II is the inaugural poet laureate for the city of Hartford. He is an associate professor of English at Three Rivers Community College in Norwich.
Libraries aren't buildings but people
By Susan Schoenberger

Each library I know brings with it the vivid memory of a librarian who put a book in my hands that changed my life.
The best example is my elementary school librarian, Patricia Myruski, whose voice I can still hear reading Roald Dahl's "James and the Giant Peach" aloud almost a half-century later. Miss Myruski would look you in the eye and, without hesitation, pull a book off the shelf as if she could see right into your thirsty little third-grade soul.
Miss Myruski was the reason I wanted to write books, if only to attempt to bring to others the kind of joy and total immersion that reading brought to me. We all need a Miss Myruski in our lives and a great library at which to make that connection.
Susan Schoenberger is the author of two novels, "A Watershed Year" and "The Virtues of Oxygen." She is director of communications at Hartford Seminary.
A sacramental quality
By Rand Richards Cooper

Over the decades, I've made sporadic visits to the Norman Williams Library, a beautiful library in an 1883 stone building on the Woodstock, Vt., town green, beginning when I was a kid vacationing with my family. More recently, I visited when my wife and I brought our young daughter to a summer day camp 20 minutes away. The cabin we rented was blessedly beyond the reach of internet, and I'd drive to Woodstock to check email on the library computers.
The building's graceful charm begins with the twin columns and triad of ornately filigreed arches at its entrance. Inside you'll find a double-wing transept and stained-glass windows, a mezzanine bordered by intricate wooden balustrades, and massive curved oak beams high above. An elongated central atrium runs nave-like through the building, books on either side in wooden shelves arranged like pews. These borrowed elements of church architecture suggest a miniature cathedral and confer a sacramental quality upon the library's function.
The Norman Williams is the first library where, many years ago as a young writer, I discovered a book of mine on the shelves. That makes the place even more sacred to me.
Rand Richards Cooper is the author of two works of fiction. He is contributing editor at Commonweal Magazine, and his writing has appeared in The New York Times, The New Yorker, Harper's, Esquire and The Atlantic. He writes a column, "In Our Midst," for Hartford Magazine.
Finding Gold
By Jeff Benedict

Books are a luxury. At least they were in my childhood home. With six children packed into a three-bedroom cottage, my parents had neither the money nor the space for books.
But my mother viewed reading and writing as a top priority. So she took us to the Waterford Public Library on a regular basis. While my younger siblings played in the children's section, I made friends with the librarian in charge of archives. At age 11, I wasn't much of a reader. However, I loved Sports Illustrated. The librarian started bringing me back issues.
Pretty soon, I was reading about Muhammad Ali, Billie Jean King, Joe Namath, and Bear Bryant - sports figures that were before my time. The concepts of archives and back issues were foreign to me. All I knew was that it felt like I was traveling back in time every time the librarian brought out another short stack of old magazines. It was so much fun that I would rather go to the library than anywhere.
Then one day, the librarian gave me two large boxes of Sports Illustrated to take home. Apparently, the library needed to create space, and the magazines would otherwise have been discarded. I still remember the stamp on the covers said: "Waterford Library." I felt like she had given me boxes of gold.
Thirty years later, I wrote my first cover story for Sports Illustrated. When I saw my name on the cover of my favorite childhood magazine, I thought back to my childhood librarian and the incredible impact she had on me. She helped me fall in love with archives, research and magazines. I'm so glad my mother brought me to the public library.
Jeff Benedict is the author of 15 nonfiction books, a Sports Illustrated contributor, and a television and film producer. In 2018, he published "Tiger Woods," with Armen Keteyian, which was a New York Times No. 1 best-seller. He is a writer-in-residence at the Garde Arts Center in New London.
A path to publishing success
By Julia Tannenbaum

As an avid reader and writer, I've always felt a strong connection to libraries. My local library, the Noah Webster Library in West Hartford, is no exception. I moved to West Hartford when I was 3 years old, and since then it has been like my second home. From Storytime in the Kid's Corner to middle school book groups to challenging writing workshops, the Noah Webster Library has played a significant role in strengthening my love for books.
This September, I published my debut novel "Changing Ways," a contemporary young adult story about a 16-year-old's journey to overcome mental illness. The Noah Webster Library staff was very supportive, with the teen librarian Kari Karp even offering to edit my manuscript prior to publication. They celebrated this accomplishment by hosting an author's talk for me. As I stood in the conference room, sharing my story with an audience of at least 30 people, I realized how fortunate I was to belong to such an incredible library.
I'm 18 now, and in a few months, I will be leaving for college. But I know that regardless of where my life takes me, I will always remember the Noah Webster Library.
Julia Tannenbaum is the author of "Changing Ways," a novel about teen mental illness. She is a senior at Hall High School in West Hartford.

Concept is clear, transition isn't

Información de publicación: Bismarck Tribune ; Bismarck, ND [Bismarck, ND]. 10 Mar 2019: 8.

https://www.proquest.com/newspapers/concept-is-clear-transition-isnt/docview/2189209619/se-2?accountid=14708

Resumen: Ninguno disponible.

Enlaces: https://upfinder.upf.edu/openurl/34CSUC_UPF/34CSUC_UPF:VU1?genre=article&amp;atitle=Concept+is+clear%2C+transition+isn%27t&amp;author=&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;spage=8&amp;date=2019-03-10&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.jtitle=Bismarck+Tribune&amp;issn=&amp;isbn=&amp;sid=ProQ%3Anorthcentralnews_

Texto completo: The Brits and Canadians I know certainly love their single-payer health care systems. If one of their politicians suggested they should switch to the American health care model, they'd throw him out the window.
So single-payer health care, or in our case "Medicare for all," is worth taking seriously. I have just never understood how we get from here to there, how we transition from our current system to the one Bernie Sanders has proposed and Elizabeth Warren, Kamala Harris and others have endorsed.
Despite differences among individual proposals, the broad outlines of Medicare for all are easy to grasp. We would take the money we're spending on private health insurance and private health care, and we would shift it over to the federal government through higher taxes in some form.
Then, since health care would be a public monopoly, the government could set prices and force health care providers to accept current Medicare payment rates. Medicare reimburses hospitals at 87 percent of costs while private insurance reimburses at 145 percent of costs. Charles Blahous, a former Social Security and Medicare public trustee, estimates that under the Sanders plan, the government could pay about 40 percent less than what private insurers now pay for treatments.
If this version of Medicare for all worked as planned, everybody would be insured, health care usage would rise sharply because it would be free, without even a co-payment, and America would spend less overall on health care.
It sounds good. But the trick is in the transition.
First, patients would have to transition. Right now, roughly 181 million Americans receive health insurance through employers. About 70 percent of these people say they are happy with their coverage. Proponents of Medicare for all are saying: We're going to take away the insurance you have and are happy with, and we're going to replace it with a new system you haven't experienced yet because, trust us, we're the federal government.
The insurance companies would have to transition. Lots of people work for and serve this industry. All-inclusive public health care would destroy this industry beyond recognition, and those people would have to find other work.
Hospitals would have to transition. In many small cities the local health care system is the biggest employer. As Reihan Salam points out in The Atlantic, the United States has far more fully stocked hospitals relative to its population and much lower bed occupancy than comparable European nations have.
If you live in a place where the health system is a big employer, think what happens when that sector takes a sudden, huge pay cut. The ripple effects would be immediate - like a small deindustrialization.
Doctors would have to transition. Salary losses would differ by specialty, but imagine you came out of med school saddled with debt and learn that your payments are going to be down by, say 30 percent. Similar shocks would ripple to other health care workers.
The American people would have to transition. Americans are more decentralized, diverse and individualistic than people in the nations with single-payer systems. They are more suspicious of centralized government and tend to dislike higher taxes.
The Sanders plan would increase federal spending by about $32.6 trillion over its first 10 years, according to a Mercatus Center study that Blahous led. Compare that with the Congressional Budget Office's projection for the entire 2019 fiscal year budget, $4.4 trillion. That kind of sticker shock is why a plan for single-payer in Vermont collapsed in 2014 and why Colorado voters overwhelmingly rejected one in 2016. It's why legislators in California killed one. In this plan, the taxes are upfront, the purported savings are down the line.
Once they learn that Medicare for all would eliminate private insurance and raise taxes, only 37 percent of Americans support it, according to a Kaiser Family Foundation survey. In 2010, Republicans scored an enormous electoral victory because voters feared that the government was taking over their health care, even though Obamacare really didn't. Now, under Medicare for all, it really would. This seems like an excellent way to re-elect Donald Trump.
The government would also have to transition. Medicare for all works only if politicians ruthlessly enforce those spending cuts. But in our system of government, members of Congress are terrible at fiscal discipline. They are quick to cater to special interest groups, terrible at saying no. To make single-payer really work, we'd probably have to scrap the U.S. Congress and move to a more centralized parliamentary system.
Finally, patient expectations would have to transition. Today, getting a doctor's appointment is annoying but not onerous. In Canada, the median wait time between seeing a general practitioner and a specialist is 8.7 weeks; between a GP referral and an orthopedic surgeon, it's nine months. That would take some adjusting.
If America were a blank slate, Medicare for all would be a plausible policy, but we are not a blank slate. At this point, the easiest way to get to a single-payer system would probably be to go back to 1776 and undo that whole American Revolution thing.
David Brooks writes a syndicated column for the New York Times.

Materia: Medicare; Health care policy; Health insurance; Politics; Hospitals; Employers

Lugar: United States--US New York Canada Colorado California Vermont

Empresa/organización: Nombre: New York Times Co; NAICS: 511110, 511120, 515112, 515120; Nombre: Congress; NAICS: 921120; Nombre: Congressional Budget Office--CBO; NAICS: 921120

Don’t blame the rain for deaths at Santa Anita, the problem is much more complicated

Autor: Henry, Jason. 

Información de publicación: Daily Breeze ; Torrance, Calif. [Torrance, Calif]. 09 Mar 2019.

https://www.proquest.com/newspapers/don-t-blame-rain-deaths-at-santa-anita-problem-is/docview/2189295646/se-2?accountid=14708

Resumen: Ninguno disponible.

Enlaces: https://upfinder.upf.edu/openurl/34CSUC_UPF/34CSUC_UPF:VU1?genre=article&amp;atitle=Don%26rsquo%3Bt+blame+the+rain+for+deaths+at+Santa+Anita%2C+the+problem+is+much+more+complicated&amp;author=Henry%2C+Jason&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;spage=&amp;date=2019-03-09&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.jtitle=Daily+Breeze&amp;issn=&amp;isbn=&amp;sid=ProQ%3Awestnews_

Texto completo: It wasn’t just the stormy weather that led to the deaths of 21 horses in less than three months at Santa Anita racetrack. More likely, it was a perfect storm, one that’s been brewing for years.
The heavy rains since December contributed, certainly, but an analysis of two decades of horse racing statistics published by the California Horsing Racing Board shows the world renowned track has weathered worse with fewer fatalities.
Just two years ago, 17 inches of rain — 2 more inches than this year — fell from December to March. Eleven horses died at the Arcadia facility in that time period.
Only two of Santa Anita’s five deadliest years from 1997 to 2018 correspond with higher-than-usual rainfall. The worst year, 71 deaths in 2011-12, was during the drought.
In this case, the various factors at play include the types of horses, the track, the training and racing schedules, and the weather’s impact on each of those, said Rick Arthur, equine medical director for the California Horse Racing Board. Necropsies on the horses will also determine if the animals had any pre-existing conditions or medication in their systems.
“It’s like a plane crash,” Arthur said in an earlier interview. “There’s seldom one factor that explains everything, and I wouldn’t expect that to be the case here.”
New protocols announced
On Friday, Tim Ritvo, chief operating officer of the Stronach Group, which owns Santa Anita and several other racetracks, announced a series of new protocols to increase safety when racing resumes later this month.
Consultants are still reviewing the weather’s impact on the main track, but the initial changes extend far beyond the rainy season. Under the new rules, Santa Anita will scrutinize horses’ medical records — even during training — and control the number of horses on the track for high-speed exercises.
On Saturday, Santa Anita announced its main dirt track would reopen at 5 a.m. Monday for limited workouts — “joggers and gallopers” only.
“Over the past four days, we’ve been able to do a great deal in terms of amending the soil and inspecting it,” said Dennis Moore, who served as track superintendent at Santa Anita until Dec. 31 and recently returned to analyze the racing surfaces.
“Things can happen even under perfect circumstances,” Moore said, “but from everything we’ve been able to learn, this track is in outstanding condition and it’s ready for training.”
Santa Anita’s fixes mirror successful changes made by the Del Mar Thoroughbred Club, which cut back on horses on the track in the mornings and tightened up its inspections in the aftermath of a disastrous 2016 summer season, with 17 deaths in 23 days.
Experts: Overuse of track a factor
The increased traffic at Santa Anita is likely one of the main factors in the deaths, according to experts.
Bad weather can upset the consistency of a track, but it also forces horses into the barns, sometimes for days, according to Richard Tedesco, a veteran track consultant with experience as a superintendent at most of Southern California’s racetracks.
Disruptions make trainers and owners anxious to get their horses back out as soon as possible. Once the gates reopen, there’s a flood of horses all at once on a track already weakened by rains.
“You’ve got all of these guys foaming at the mouth to get their horse ready again,” Tedesco said. “The dirt gets pretty well chewed up.”
Too many horses running at the same time is an accident waiting to happen, he said.
Santa Anita shut its track down for two days at the end of February in response to outcry over the first 19 deaths. Track expert Mick Peterson, of the University of Kentucky’s Agricultural Equine Programs, examined and cleared the course as “100 percent ready” before the track reopened Feb. 28.
The horse racing statistics website Equibase tracked 862 workouts in the six days following the reopening. On March 1, 326 horses hit the track before the afternoon races began. Then another 70 ran in those events. The 20th horse died in a race the next day. On March 5, 273 horses worked on the track where the 21st horse died.
“That’s quite a bit,” Tedesco said of the workouts. He estimates an average day is about 150 horses.
In Europe, horses exercise at training centers and race mostly on the weekends, Tedesco said. But in Southern California, the loss of venues has condensed much of the thoroughbred racing to Santa Anita. Trainers say they don’t change locations as often as they did in the past.
Santa Anita scaled up and extended its season when Hollywood Park closed in 2013.
“The bulk of the dates went to Santa Anita,” said Jack Liebau, the director of Los Alamitos Thoroughbred Racing in Orange County. “You have a lot more stress on the track and it’s difficult.”
‘Real art form’ to maintain a track
Heavy rains, a well-worn track, and even the loss of Moore as track superintendent may have all played a part, Liebau said.
Moore, who most recently has been serving as a consultant at Del Mar and Los Alamitos, helped Del Mar with its crisis in 2016. He returned to Santa Anita as a consultant earlier this month to help with the track inspections.
“It’s a real art form to maintain a track in a safe manner,” Liebau said. “Everybody seems to be very happy that Dennis is back.”
Fewer deaths at Los Alamitos
At Los Alamitos Race Course, which runs quarter horses and thoroughbreds, 10,354 horses raced last year, compared to 8,922 at Santa Anita, according to statistics compiled from reports by the CHRB.
Los Alamitos also uses a dirt main track, like Santa Anita, and in the past three months experienced heavier rain. At both venues, the track is tightly compacted to keep out moisture. This creates another potential risk as the harder-than-expected surface can throw off a horse’s fragile footing.
Since Dec. 26, only three horses have died on the track at Los Alamitos, compared to the 21 at Santa Anita. That’s despite the fact that the state’s data shows Los Alamitos had 23 percent more deaths per year on average in the past decade.
Though the tracks share similarities, the big difference between the two venues is the daily traffic. Nine of Santa Anita’s 21 deaths occurred during training on the dirt track, seven were during races. The other five happened on the venue’s storied turf track.
Los Alamitos has added more thoroughbred racing in recent years, but the majority of horses at the venue are quarter horses. These sprinters of the racing world have less intensive training regimens than thoroughbreds, Santa Anita’s bread and butter.
Los Alamitos had less than 200 workouts in the same six day period as Santa Anita’s 862, according to Equibase.
‘Everybody worried’
Last week, the New York Times reported that trainers at Santa Anita appear to be more demanding than counterparts elsewhere in the state. Santa Anita averages 3.02 workouts per start, compared with 0.88 workouts per start for horses running at Gulfstream Park in Florida and 0.42 at Aqueduct in New York.
“Ninety-nine percent of the trainers take very good care of their horses, there’s less than 1 percent that you have to watch,” said Tedesco, the track consultant. “Owners spend a lot of money, the trainers want to win races. It all comes down to, ‘Let’s keep them going.’ “
Everyone at the track is working to ensure safety of horses during training and the races, he said. Tedesco said he’s fielded concerned calls from racetrack officials across the country..
“What is going on is really bad for the industry,” he said. “It’s gotten everybody worried, everywhere.”

1945: During World War II, U.S. B-29 bombers began launching incendiary bomb attacks against Tokyo, resulting in an estimated 100,000 deaths.

1964: The U.S. Supreme Court, in New York Times Co. v. Sullivan, raised the standard for public officials to prove they'd been libeled in their official capacity by news organizations.

This day in history

Información de publicación: Boston Globe ; Boston, Mass. [Boston, Mass]. 09 Mar 2019: A.5.

https://www.proquest.com/newspapers/this-day-history/docview/2189168330/se-2?accountid=14708

Enlaces: https://upfinder.upf.edu/openurl/34CSUC_UPF/34CSUC_UPF:VU1?genre=article&amp;atitle=This+day+in+history&amp;author=&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;spage=A.5&amp;date=2019-03-09&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.jtitle=Boston+Globe&amp;issn=0743-1791&amp;isbn=&amp;sid=ProQ%3Anortheastnews1_

Texto completo: Today is Saturday, March 9, the 68th day of 2019. There are 297 days left in the year.
Birthdays: Singer Lloyd Price is 86. Actress Joyce Van Patten is 85. Actress Trish Van Devere is 78. Singer-musician John Cale (the Velvet Underground) is 77. Former ABC anchorman Charles Gibson is 76. Rock musician Robin Trower is 74. Singer Jeffrey Osborne is 71. Actress Jaime Lyn Bauer is 70. Magazine editor Michael Kinsley is 68. TV newscaster Faith Daniels is 62. Actress Linda Fiorentino is 61. Actor Tom Amandes is 60. Actor-director Lonny Price is 60. Actress Juliette Binoche is 55. Rock musician Robert Sledge (Ben Folds Five) is 51. Rock musician Shannon Leto (30 Seconds to Mars) is 49. Rapper C-Murder (a.k.a. C-Miller) is 48. Actor Emmanuel Lewis is 48. Actress Jean Louisa Kelly is 47. Actor Oscar Isaac is 40. Comedian Jordan Klepper (TV: “The Daily Show") is 40. Actor Matthew Gray Gubler is 39. Roots rock musician Ben Tanner (Alabama Shakes) is 36. Actress Brittany Snow is 33. Rapper Bow Wow is 32. Rapper YG is 29. Actor Luis Armand Garcia is 27. Actress Cierra Ramirez is 24.
In 1796, the future emperor of the French, Napoleon Bonaparte, married Josephine de Beauharnais. (The couple later divorced.)
In 1841, the US Supreme Court, in United States v. The Amistad, ruled 7-1 in favor of a group of illegally enslaved Africans who were captured off the US coast after seizing control of a Spanish schooner, La Amistad; the justices ruled that the Africans should be set free.
In 1862, during the Civil War, the ironclads USS Monitor and CSS Virginia (formerly USS Merrimac) clashed for five hours to a draw at Hampton Roads, Virginia.
In 1916, more than 400 Mexican raiders led by Pancho Villa attacked Columbus, New Mexico, killing 18 Americans. During the First World War, Germany declared war on Portugal.
In 1935, the animated cartoon character Porky Pig first appeared in the Warner Bros. animated short “I Haven't Got a Hat."
In 1945, during World War II, US B-29 bombers began launching incendiary bomb attacks against Tokyo, resulting in an estimated 100,000 deaths.
In 1954, CBS newsman Edward R. Murrow critically reviewed Wisconsin Sen. Joseph R. McCarthy's anti-communism campaign on “See It Now."
In 1964, the US Supreme Court, in New York Times Co. v. Sullivan, raised the standard for public officials to prove they'd been libeled in their official capacity by news organizations.
In 1976, a cable car in the Italian ski resort of Cavalese fell some 700 feet to the ground when a supporting line snapped, killing 43 people.
In 1977, about a dozen armed Hanafi Muslims invaded three buildings in Washington, D.C., killing one person and taking more than 130 hostages. (The siege ended two days later.)
In 1997, gangsta rapper the Notorious B.I.G. was killed in a still-unsolved drive-by shooting in Los Angeles; he was 24.
In 2009, President Barack Obama lifted George W. Bush-era limits on using federal dollars for embryonic stem cell research.
In 2014, the search continued for Malaysia Airlines Flight MH370, a Boeing 777 that had gone missing the day before while over the South China Sea with 239 people on board. (The plane was never found.)
In 2018, weeks after the shooting that left 17 people dead at a Florida high school, Govenor Rick Scott signed a school-safety bill that included new restrictions on guns, prompting a lawsuit from the National Rifle Association; the bill raised the minimum age to buy rifles to 21 and created a program enabling some teachers and other school employees to carry guns. A Kentucky neighbor of US Senator Rand Paul, Rene Boucher, pleaded guilty to a federal charge for tackling the lawmaker in an attack his attorney said was triggered by a dispute over lawn maintenance; Boucher served a 30-day prison sentence.

How Democrats emboldened anti-Semites this week

Autor: Lowe, Tiana. 

Información de publicación: Washington Examiner ; Washington, D.C. [Washington, D.C]. 08 Mar 2019.

https://www.proquest.com/newspapers/how-democrats-emboldened-anti-semites-this-week/docview/2191432617/se-2?accountid=14708

Resumen: Ninguno disponible.

Enlaces: https://upfinder.upf.edu/openurl/34CSUC_UPF/34CSUC_UPF:VU1?genre=article&amp;atitle=How+Democrats+emboldened+anti-Semites+this+week&amp;author=Lowe%2C+Tiana&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;spage=&amp;date=2019-03-08&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.jtitle=Washington+Examiner&amp;issn=&amp;isbn=&amp;sid=ProQ%3Asoutheastnews_

Texto completo: Doctors warn you to finish complete rounds of antibiotics, even if an infection feels better, in order to prevent the bacteria from developing antibiotic resistance.

Shame has the same relation with racists and anti-Semites. That's why halfhearted critiques of Rep. Steve King, R-Iowa, only empowered his racism, to the point that he was came to equate Mexicans to "dirt" on the campaign trail and defend white supremacy to the New York Times.

Well, congratulations, Democrats. You didn't finish your medicine. You passed a pathetic excuse of an "All Lives Matter" denunciation of hate on all sides, and now the sickness is catching. You didn't teach Rep. Ilhan Omar, D-Minn., one lick of empathy or humility. Instead, her anti-Semitism has gained mainstream support in the Democratic Party. It is now shame-resistant, and she'll be more vocal than ever with it.

Don't believe me? It's already happening. The vote on the "anti-Semitism" resolution occurred not 24 hours ago, and Omar's already hit the ground running on her victory lap.

In a joint statement with Rep. Rashida Tlaib, D-Mich. (the only sitting congresswoman to openly support the eradication of Israel) and Rep. Andre Carson, D-Ind., Omar celebrated the "historic" day. Why? Because "it's the first time we have voted on a resolution condemning anti-Muslim bigotry in our nation's history."

Remember: Omar's anti-Semitism was the reason for this resolution. Instead of learning a lesson from it, she's learned she is untouchable.

A few hours after that, Omar retweeted Mehdi Hasan mocking Meghan McCain for becoming visibly upset on television regarding Omar's comments.This disgraceful result is really the result of Nancy Pelosi's abrupt cowardice. She would have done less harm by delivering a milquetoast critique and, say, simply avoided posing on a national magazine cover with her. By calling out Omar and then chickening out, she handed Omar a major political victory instead of the rebuke she deserved.

Congresswoman Omar won. Less than a month ago she was coerced into a half-hearted apology. Now she's brimming with unabashed pride over her ability to shut down the saner denizens of her party.

Any veneer of contrition from Omar has been shot to hell by the Democrats' dereliction of duty in calling out hate in their ranks. Omar's first apology following the "Benjamins" catastrophe was "unequivocal." Her second was a big, fat sorry to anyone whose feelings she hurt. Now there is none. Just sheer glee and giant "up-yours" to every Jew in the country who felt rattled by her invocation of multiple anti-Semitic stereotypes.

It will only get worse. Just as we saw strains of the French protectionist Right migrate across the Atlantic into the 2016 election, the Corbynization of the Democratic Party is well underway. Even the nominal facade of Jewish and Israeli tolerance has been shed, not just by one member of the House, but by every hateful hack who enabled her.

Yes, the anti-Semitism of the Left that percolated from college dorm rooms to the Women's March and finally to the hallowed halls of Congress is at last shame-resistant, and it's here to stay.

Preventive Medicine: A breathless end to diet doubts

Autor: Katz, David. 

Información de publicación: New Haven Register ; New Haven, Conn. [New Haven, Conn]. 08 Mar 2019.

https://www.proquest.com/newspapers/preventive-medicine-breathless-end-diet-doubts/docview/2189212887/se-2?accountid=14708

Resumen: Ninguno disponible.

Enlaces: https://upfinder.upf.edu/openurl/34CSUC_UPF/34CSUC_UPF:VU1?genre=article&amp;atitle=Preventive+Medicine%3A+A+breathless+end+to+diet+doubts&amp;author=Katz%2C+David&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;spage=&amp;date=2019-03-08&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.jtitle=New+Haven+Register&amp;issn=&amp;isbn=&amp;sid=ProQ%3Anortheastnews1_

Texto completo: Within just the past week or so, expert commentary in the New York Times told us first that we need better nutrition answers, and then, that we need artificial intelligence to feed Homo sapiens well. Personally, I doubt the advent of artificial intelligence excuses use of the natural version.
And so, with a bow to the native, natural intelligence for which our species is known, I propose you join me in a thought experiment before you decide what, or whether, to eat. Let’s think about breathing the way we are so often goaded to think about eating.
We hold this truth to be self-evident: that humans are adapted to breathe air, not water. But should we, really, hold that as self-evident truth? After all — there have been no randomized controlled trials (RCTs) to clinch the matter.
These days, on the topic of nutrition in particular, authorities compete to be first in line to advocate more RCTs. We have been told we are confused, misled, and mired in doubt — all for want of those definitive RCTs, and now — a missing pinch of artificial intelligence (A.I.) too.
If that’s true, and if what’s good for the gut of the goose is just as good for the lungs of the gander, then we must question the brazen conclusion that we should be breathing air, not water. We have no randomization to lean on; no double-blinding; no testing with placebo air. And while we are at it, we also have no data about conferring with our microbiome; no applications of artificial intelligence to the topic; no probing consideration of the subtleties of genetic predisposition (“pneumogenomics”).
It’s premature to conclude we should breathe air. There’s just so much we don’t know. Much as it feels good, maybe breathing air is a bad idea. Much as it feels bad, maybe breathing under water is better. All we have to argue the other way is…anecdotes. We all know what those are worth.
Even if breathing air is better, that leaves far too much detail unaddressed to just start inhaling. Is there interaction between the air and the microbiome? We really ought to hit pause on breathing until we sort out the all-important preferences of our resident bacteria. Do they prefer fast or slow? Hot or cold? Misty sea air, or rarefied mountain air?
Adaptation, you say? Sure, there is the mix of gases native to the atmosphere of this planet, and that’s just what our species has always been breathing. But that’s obviously a very feeble perch from which to make the mad leap of faith that the native air of Earth is what’s “right” for us. Our kind of creature, to borrow from The Martian, needs to science the “expletive” out of something before getting to the sense of it. We can’t take this stuff for granted.
And the idea that the same kind of air might be good for all of us? Well, that’s just so last-news-cycle. Almost offensive, really. These days, our air really ought to be customized, personalized, and precision before we can deign to breathe the stuff. One-size-fits-all air is just not…inspiring.
So much for the thought experiment; what does all this hot air have to do with diet? Well, what we know about air and breathing, we know about food and eating — for all the same reasons, and in all the same ways. Except that in the case of food and eating, we actually do have RCTs, too. And vast troves of evidence in many other flavors, besides — from basic, mechanistic research, to observational epidemiology at the level of whole populations over generations. All of that nutrition science first begins where our understanding of human breathing ends — with simple observation of what’s what.
Since despite the addition of science to sense experts keep telling us — again, and again, and again — that we are clueless about the basic feeding of Homo sapiens, how much more so when it comes to breathing — where we only have sense and some misguided infatuation with what’s obvious, but much, much less science?
My advice, then, is also obvious. We need not wait for a new, national institute or advances in artificial intelligence to embrace and apply the fundamental truths of healthful eating. Those who do feel obligated to wait have all the same reasons to hold their breath while they’re at it.
Dr. David L. Katz Author, The Truth about Food
Crédito: Dr. David Katz

Materia: Artificial intelligence; Nutrition; Preventive medicine

Lugar: New York

Personas: Katz, David L
